item.title: The Beginning of a New Journey Part 2
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The canoe trip ended up being a great camping session with David becoming the master chef of fresh filets (fish from the lake to your plate is a meal that will be tough to beat), Luke learning to fish from the front of a canoe with no one steering, and spending many below freezing nights with a nothing but a barn burner and a bottle of blackout sauce.  Zen (the book) helped me reignite my passion to take a trip like this and I actually took a day to spell out places I would want to visit, people I want to catch up with, reasons why/why not to take the trip, and things to take care of before heading out.  The idea was to do it in 6 months, but when I got back to Houston I got an invite from an old Aussie buddy to come out to Bonnaroo as they had an extra ticket.  I was not on any particular project at work at the time, so I was luckily able to get time off to take the last minute trip. Two weeks later I am at Bonnaroo with Luke with 4 Aussies seeing many of the bands I love; Ratatat, Mumford and Sons, Arcade Fire, Gogol Bordello and Explosions in the Sky.  It was an amazing weekend filled with great music, endless laughter and 3 bro’s who would help shape where I am now. When I returned from the festival I had lunch with a good friend who announced that he wife was pregnant!  I am really stoked for people who are at that stage in their life and look forward to those days.  I told him about Bonnaroo and that 3 of the Aussies were actually starting a trip through Central and South America for the next 8 months.  His immediate response to this was, “you’re going with them right?”  I actually had not even considered it, but as soon as it was said, I felt that I should really give it serious consideration. As soon as I was back at work I messaged the guys to see if we could talk and so I could gage their interest in having a random America dude join them for the next 8 months.  As the days ticked by that week I knew that my window to get out and start a journey was shrinking as we had a big client meeting that Friday and I knew that if I attended I would be locked into the project for the next few months.  That Thursday I spoke with a few work friends about the situation and decided that it would be best to miss the meeting Friday and take the weekend to sort things out and hopefully hear back from the Aussies. After work I went to have a beer with my buddy/priest and told him this story.  I communicated that I was very much up in the air about what to do next, but that I had at least the weekend to sort it out.  Once I had caught him up to the current moment, he raised his glass and said, “Here is to your last day at work.  If the Aussies don’t respond then you should pull out a map point to a spot and go there.”  This hit me deep and I knew that he was right.  I had already been planning a trip like this, so why not do it now?  I had the money, no debts, my lease was up, and motivation to do it.  I went into work the next morning and told them I was going to be taking a leave, to which they were very receptive and understanding, which I am very grateful for.  They have been nothing but supportive and I think that is an awesome quality and the kind of company I want to be working at. I was free and it felt great.  I did not know where I would be going or how soon it would be, but I knew I would be on the road soon, chasing my dreams and starting a new journey. Later that weekend I heard from the Aussies and it turned out that the past few months/years they had really planed on just having the 3 of them on the journey and they never considered having another person along for an extended amount of time.  This was partially what I expected and was even refreshing, as I now knew that I would be blazing my own trail. By the middle of the next week I had booked my flights and had a plan for the next 6 months locked in as well as a tentative plan for the next 2 years. As I sit here drinking hot tea in first class I know I am incredibly blessed to be in a position in life that I can take a trip like this.  I cannot fully understand how blessed I am as I do not know intimately the struggles others are going through in their lives or barriers they have to a trip like this.  It is definitely something that I will have on my mind throughout this trip and hope to have a better understanding of.  For now I see it as I should not feel bad for the life I have, but instead enjoy it and look for opportunities to serve others who are not as fortunate.  I also worked hard to get here (yeah, definitely not as hard as some would have to, but there will always be someone who went through more to get where you are) and made decisions that set me up nicely to be able to walk away from everything quickly and be able to start this. First pass at my goals/things to try:
  • Learn a new language
  • Get better at remembering names
  • Run a marathon on each continent (still considering this one)
  • Bike across New Zealand (also more of an option than a goal currently)
  • Fasting
Current plan:
  • 3 weeks in a tree house with the fastest Wi-Fi in Costa Rica
  • 1 week in Colorado our yearly family trip to Boulder
  • 2 months in New Zealand for the Rugby World Cup and to see old friends
  • 2 weeks in Bali to surf and meet folks
  • 2 weeks in Jakarta
  • Fly to Singapore and travel inland for a while
  • I hope to meet two friends in India at this point and then the plan is pretty high level from there.
Current things I am listening to on my iPod:
  • Atmosphere – When Life gives you Lemons
  • Explosions in the Sky – all of it
  • Wait Wait Don’t Tell Me – NPR
  • The Pipeline with Dan Benjamin
  • Dubstep – the nasty kind
Current books/articles I am wading through:
  • The Language Hacking Guide by Benny Lewis
  • Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
  • In a Sunburned Country – Bill Bryson
  • Ruby on Rails Guides
Thanks to Jeno for sharing the Houston experience with me and helping me stay motived to see more of the city.  Thanks also for the tips on women, even when it gets me in a bit of a mess. Thanks to my parents for taking me around the country as a kid, when I know I was a brat fighting with my siblings and being a picky eater. Thanks to my sister for always encouraging me to jump into these type of things and leading by example! Thanks to my brother for always lending an ear and calling me out when I get a little too Zen. Thanks to my many other friends for the support, recommendations, and beers the last few weeks before I head out. I hope to keep this blog up to date with pictures and stories in the coming years and I hope that I can meet many of you on the road. Cheers! *** Sorry for the grammar and spelling mistakes that surely exist.  Please shoot me a note if you find one.  I am more interested in getting thoughts down and getting back to life than worrying about such things. Here is a picture of Luke’s master fishing skills and David cheffin’ it up: [caption id="attachment_8" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Canoeing in the boundary waters"][/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: get it BRO
I couldn't be more excited for you if I tried! Please be safe...and no licking of the frogs in Costa Rica.
Good luck on your journey! Our prayers will be with you for a wonderful, safe, and enriching time! We are looking forward to keeping up with all of your adventures. :)
Thanks for the support!

item.title: Exploring a bike across New Zealand during the Rugby World Cup
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I am definitely considering making a trip across New Zealand to cover much of its beautiful terrain via bike. There are 13 cities in which games are taking place during September and October. I will be in the country from September 6th to November 5th, providing 60 days to get around the islands. Making a first pass at the route basing it on hitting every town where games take place (not necessarily when the games are going on) would make the trip around 2100 miles. This breaks down to just over 35 miles a day, which is more than doable. The question is would the schedule work out for me to be in the cities when the games are happening. I will have to analyze that on the next flight. Here is a link to the route: http://goo.gl/KW2Xl I wonder if I could get sponsored or get tickets for doing something like this. I would need to promote something...ideas?

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
My name is Andrew Cobb and I am an IT Consultant who took a leave from the daily grind to go out and travel around the world. This blog is to document the journey and share some of the more interesting experiences I come across.
...and yes, I did mean to call it wondering!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Love it. Will be following along, my friend!

This is awesome. Good luck and enjoy every second.
...let me know if you ever need any border crossing tips, especially when you hit SE Asia ;)
Thanks Fred, I am sure I will be reaching out in the near future!

item.title: The beginning of a new journey part 1
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I have been going back and forth on creating a travel blog, and after starting to read The Language Hacking Guide by Benny Lewis (thanks Schiffli), I have decided to stop delaying and start it. Where to start?  It was about 6 weeks ago that I took a leave from my job and decided to start realizing my dream of travelling the world.  It is something I have desired specifically since college, but there have been undertones of it going much further back.  My parents were always good about taking us on trips to see family around the states and my church took me to see more of the country as well as Central America.  I enjoy meeting new people and learning about their culture as I am curious about whom has it right.  I know that no one has it down perfectly, but I believe that you can learn a lot from experiences what others day to day life is like and then you can let those stories influence and hopefully change you for the better. I am on my way to Cape Cod at the moment to see my uncle, brother, sister in law, and mother.  Sounds like we will be doing a bit of golfing and boating.  This is a trip I used to take a lot as a kid and always enjoyed.  We would take the train from Longview, TX up through the heartland of America into Chicago, and then on to Boston.  From there we would usually rent a car and then spend a few weeks with my grandparents on the Cape.  I really enjoyed the time we spent on the train; looking out the window at the passing cities and country side, playing checkers with my brother, and wrestling with my sis.  I remember listening to Dr. Dre, Chronic 2001 and The Pharcyde, Labcabincalifornia thinking that I need to cherish each moment on the train, as it wouldn’t last long and that we likely wouldn’t be coming back as my grandparents had moved or passed.  That was probably my first acknowledgement of The Now, which was back in early high school.  The Now, is not a new idea by any stretch, and I am sure people probably even refer to it the same way, but it is something that really motivates me and excites me from the time I wake up until the last beer is served.  There is a long story to go with it, but for now I can just say that it is all about living in the moment; there is no tomorrow, no yesterday, no worries, just now. I just got back from spending a weekend in Galveston with work friends.  We did a bit of beach time, some bay fishing, and plenty of boozing.  It is pretty sweet to spend a weekend with smart, talented people who have big ambitions (trying to create a sane alternative to consulting) or simple but heavy ones (working for only bread and water). I have a lot of work friends who are getting married or starting families and I am endlessly excited for them.  It is something that I want in the future, but there is a lot I want to see before then.  I have actually been reading some interesting travel blogs of couples and even families that travel for extended amounts of time.  In the case of the family, they always have their baby sleep in a hammock so that we they travel they can bring the hammock and the baby will sleep well as it is familiar with its banana bed. There are definitely selfish reasons for this trip, or maybe they all are.  One of which is that when travelling to a new country you are often treated like the most interesting person in the world, for no other reason than that you are from somewhere else.  This treatment is definitely dampened in heavily touristy areas, but if you can get off the path and meet the locals, you will often be treated with a surprisingly warm welcome. Anyhow, back to where I was.  I went on several mission trips in high school to Honduras to help build houses and help fix up schools and churches.  I know there is a stigmatism associated with doing this type of thing with a church, as many believe that you should not be forcing your religion upon others.  I do agree with this mentality, but for me these trips were about sharing experiences and if they liked where we came from we could offer helping hands and even religion, but of course, only if that was what they were interested in.  I was fascinated on these trips about how simply the Hondurans lived their lives and how few things they had, but how happy they were at the end of the day.  Friends and family were truly first priority in their culture, and that appeared to have a big impact on their happiness. Taking the leap to start this current journey started about 8 weeks ago.  I took a scheduled vacation to The Boundary Waters between Minnesota and Canada with my Canuck friend Luke and my brother David.  We have done this canoe trip before, but we approached this one with a very different goal.  In the weeks leading up to the trip we spoke about only taking the bare minimum food for the trip.  We would take some starch (rice and tortillas), snacks (Mama Cobb’s trail mix), and breakfast (oatmeal).  The idea was that if you wanted to have a full meal and not be hungry all the time, then you had to catch some damn fish!  While we had lighter packs due to the reduced amount of food, we easily made up that weight with every type of lure, jig, repalla, worm, stink bait, spinner, and tickler you could think of.  Even with this goal of fishing our asses off, I think we were still thinking about covering lots of water on the trip, as that is what an A-Team trip is.  However, this direction took a hit on the flight out when Luke expressed interest in actually focusing on fishing and setting up sweet campsites instead of going hard all day, trolling for fish, and then being exhausted when it came time to gut and cook the fish.  This change in direction ended up being the greatest audible we have had on a trip in a long time.  It might seem like a simple decision, but it completely changed the mentality of the trip and relaxed out bodies, minds, and spirits as we could actually focus on the beauty of the Canadian outback instead of on crushing miles on miles and rods on rods.  Don’t get me wrong; I love crushing trails as much as the next guy, but this was an awesome change of pace. This post is getting pretty long, so I will continue it on a new one...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I demand a name drop on this blog. Also, your wp theme is silly as hell.

item.title: So it begins...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This post is inspired by my dear and often brutally honest friend Niv, who is studying to become a teacher for the youth of America. He posed a few questions before I headed out and I found them to be a good way to get things going on this journey. What is the number one thing I will miss? There are lots of things I enjoyed in Houston, and in my time there my goal was to do it as hard as possible so that I could say I gave it my all and really feel that I had experienced it. The city did not disappoint and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a laid back atmosphere at bars and a low cost of living. That doesn’t answer the question though. I really enjoyed biking in the city: to restaurants, bars, and friend’s houses. The city does not have the best bike lane infrastructure, but trails like the TC Jester bike path are expanding more everyday. Bikes are a great way to see any city and get exercise while doing it. That of course is just an activity I will miss, but of course it is friends and family that will really leave a hole in my pocket. I met many great people through work and play and am glad to have shared time with them in Houston. What is the number one thing I will not miss? I think the biggest thing that disturbs me about the States right now are the politics and the general feeling of fear that keeps people locked in their homes and following party lines. 24 hour news stations have to show something and what they believe keeps people watching is the threat of your children being kidnapped, being run over by your wife, murdering your children, armed burglary, etc. These threats are out there, but waiting for them to happen doesn’t prevent them from happening. I think that fear is probably an easier emotion to trigger than love and essentially these stations are taking the easy route by selling fear instead of inspiring stories of love and compassion. Every station has an agenda whether you want them to or not, its just unfortunate to me that stories of apartment fires and congress being unable to have constructive and logical discussion might be the only stories that foreigners would see if they watched 30 minutes of our news. What is the number one thing I am looking forward to? I am most excited about starting new habits. I hope to focus more on running, reading, meditating, and slowing down to take in what the world has to offer. What is the number one thing I am least looking forward to? I am most nervous about learning a new language. I am not staying in a non-English speaking country for more than a month for the first 6 months of my travels, so I won’t have much time to immerse myself in any one language. It will probably be next summer before I am in one country for more than a month, but even with it so far off it still feels daunting to learn an entirely new vocabulary. Current Books: 4 hour work week Born to run Music: Mumford and Sons Washed Out – Within and Without The journey starts today in San Jose, Costa Rica!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Bon voyage, my friend. Very excited for you. See you out there!!

Good luck, have fun!
The language thing is frustrating at first, but then you just get used to body language and pointing and getting lost and seeing what you end up with. Or you can always just go find a young person who can always speak some English...

item.title: San Jose, Costa Rica
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: San Jose, Costa Rica is just like any thriving metropolis. This photo montage should help clarify. McDonalds is the most popular spot on the block… Buses have no problem trying to take you out… You can have you pick of popular movies via street homies… You can find a weapon that fits your needs and budget… There are strange food to try that make you feel weird but taste sooo good. These mamonas are the bomb… You can get assigned clever nicknames like Blanco Amigo con Mamonas... Public parks where futbol players and bums can coexist... And there are, of course, ample gansta ass kicks to choose from… What's a city without the Circo de Chine Beijing es Dragon! Ahh, San Jose, you do not disappoint.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Busted image links!

item.title: Uvita, Costa Rica
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Yesterday I took a 5-hour shuttle ride from San Jose thru Jaco and Manuel Antonio down to Uvita.   Roberto, the driver, was very friendly and very interested in communicating to me that there are plenty of cervesas (beers) and muyeras (women) in Uvita.  I was actually able to make a few short conversations about the weather, futbol, women, family, etc.  When you are forced to be in a car for 5 hours with one dude who doesn’t speak English, then you make due with the vocab you have. I arrived with enough time to setup my tent in the tree house, as I was advised to do so as the hammock wouldn’t provide much protection with the impending monsoon on the way.  I got the tent up and was enjoying my PB&J inside it when the rain started coming down.  I am only 100ft from the main covered area of the hostel, but it was daunting thinking I would have to make it back there to drop off any goods I didn’t want stolen. When I arrived at Hotel Tucan Tra (Tray), the owner spoke with me for a bit and gave me the low down on the area.  I got a 30-minute lecture on the importance of hiding or locking up my shit up because the local kids are very good at stealing things.  He said that they are organized and watch where you burry your stuff on the beach and then attack while you are out surfing/swimming.  He even said that they sneak into the hostel and into the rooms while people sleep and try to grab whatever they can.  How comforting!  I want to talk to Travis to see if he feels if it really is that bad. It was a long night as the tree house is near the main road and they are tons of dogs, roosters, and other rodents making all the ruckus they can.  I think it will take a few days to get used to, but should be fine. This morning I met us with my America buddy Travis who moved here to marry a Tica and run a surf shop.  He is also really involved with volunteering in the community and invited me to come out to a school called La Flor de Bahia.  They had a real problem with drainage from the kitchen that serves 300 kids a day.  It was creating a nasty lake, which was home to mesquitos and other insects that could carry such wonderful things as malaria.  They have now put in piping from the sinks and then send it through several filtration systems in the yard that collect solids and even clean to water back to a state in which it can be used for cleaning again.  We worked on the 3rd filtration step which sends the water over rocks before sending it through more piping. There was a group of high school students at the school as well who are in Costa Rica for a week to volunteer and surf.  They spend their mornings doing community projects and then head to the beach in the afternoon for hands on surf instructions!  Sounds like a pretty sweet program to me. I am currently checking out http://www.tucanhotel.com/ as the owner wants to create a mobile version for the more technologically advanced travellers, which there are apparently a lot of. [gallery] Cheers!

item.title: A slew of firsts
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The last two days have been all about new experiences.  Here is a list of those that come to mind:
  • Drank two coups of coffee in a week’s time for the first time ever.  Everyone is offering, so I can’t say no.
  • Finally saw a mono congo (howler monkey) in the wild.  A family of them were hanging out in the forest on the beach.
  • Enjoyed fresh coconut with Sujey, Travis’s neighbor, who cut it up for me and offered me the tall glass of milk, which apparently is called aqua de pipa, which refers to the unripe coconut, which is a bit strange.  Something might have been lost in translation.
  • Watched a local four year old girl stand up on a board and ride it with very little help from her father.
  • Spoke of peace and alternative economies, which would have different motives than those of western societies.  Western societies are always focused on growth and consuming greater and greater amounts of wealth, but this often leaves people void of spiritual and moral truth (highly influenced and stolen from: Small is Beautiful – E.F. Schumacher).  Schumacher instead says our work should satisfy all of our earthly needs and not so much on greed and living beyond what we truly need.  It’s a very interesting read and I am wondering how much of it could work in the US.  I think if you found a few like-minded individuals, you could certainly make a run at it.
  • Had meat and beer for the first time in a week, and felt terrible from eating it.
  • Experienced a bamboo rainforest.
  • Meditated in a treehouse.
  • Broke a surfboard leash.
  • Broke a surfboard.
  • Got bit by this bitch ass dog:
Much too look forward to.  Much to reflect on. Thanks for tuning in.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Editing Police - Got "bit" by a.....don't drink too much of the alternative kool-aid please, I'd like for you to return to the states sometime.
Thanks bro.

item.title: Bodhi Surf School
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: My surf school buddy down here, Travis, runs Bodhi Surf school that focuses on creating a wholistic approach to calming your mind and spirit thru surfing and yoga and other activities.  It is a great way to make a vacation and actual vacation! Here is a better summary from the man himself: Looking for a unique vacation experience? Bodhi Surf School invites you to reconnect with nature through surfing, yoga, whale watching, and other outdoor activities. Located in Uvita, Costa Rica we offer private surf lessons, group surf lessons, surf clinics and vacation packages for families and small groups. Costa Rica, a safe and popular travel destination, is known for its natural beauty and beginner-friendly surf conditions. Visit us online at www.bodhisurfschool.com for more information. Go for the full week package.  You won't regret it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: All I'm able to say is wow. I have in no way looked at it like that, but I appreicate you posting it. I will continue to become a regular reader of the blog.

item.title: Finally, I got up
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: It took 5 days and many other failed attempts on previous trips, but I was finally able to paddle myself out to the big boy waves, get on one when it was at a 45 degree angel, hop on my surfboard before the wave crashed, and ride southward.  That, my friends, is what surfing is all about.  Unfortunately, there was no barrel to own, but the joy of riding an unbroken wave and controlling the direction of the board as the wave finally crashes, is a pretty sick feeling.  Props to Travis and Bodhi Surf School for some crucial tips to help me make this last step.  They also have really nice beginner boards that float easily and are long and wide enough to make for easy controlled riding. I have been running, reading, meditating, eating, working on my Spanish, and surfing the past two days.  Travis has two dogs that love to run and will join along even when they were not invited!  Luckily they provide a lot of entertainment and motivation along the route.  This morning it was low tide so I was able to make it down to the whales tail: Source: http://www.dolphintourcostarica.com/images/photos/whale_tail_uvita.jpg At the point of the tail, one dog snatched up a little red crab and had a delicious dessert to his breakfast.  The other dog, Collie, is one of the fastest animals I have ever seen on four feet.  His pleasure on the route came from chasing birds on the beach.  He was often faster than the birds, but since they had the added defense mechanism of flight, they often got away. I have been doing pretty well to stay within my $54/day budget.  It was hard at first, as travel days and the city are expensive, but once I got to the small town of Uvita, it became a little easier.  I have only paid for one night since I got hear as I stayed with Travis for a few days and then provided some mobile website tips for a few more nights.  I have been feasting on such fine cuisines as PB&J and Fruit Loops, which runs a few bucks a day.  I actually splurged today and got some eggs and peppers to make some pretty bomb tacos. I am now staying at the Flutterby House, which is closer to the beach and between the to ranger stations you see on the map below: Source: http://www.moon.com/files/map-images/ctr_07_Uvita.jpg Looking forward to what is next!

item.title: Philanthropic Travel
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I have been introduced to the idea of Philanthropic Travel, which is all about empowering local communities through social, educational, health and environmental initiatives. From my limited understanding, it's all about bringing your time, treasure, or talent to a community and sharing it with them. Time is well, time, to lend a helping hand or do whatever they need. Treasure would be providing monetary assistance. Talent is bring your skills to these small communities and either teaching them those skills or providing them with services that are needed. I am very interested in using the programming experience I have to help small businesses, communities, and foundations get sites up and get connected to the web in whatever way they need.
It has been fascinating to see how many opportunities are in this space, even in the past two weeks. I have spoken to several people providing either high level guidance or even sitting with people to show them how easy it is to get up and going.
I most recently met a Costa Rican, Irina, who is interested in starting a foundation to teach kids math and science, since the public education system down here is really lacking in those areas. She was interested in creating a desktop application that would provide questions, answers, and explanations, but I showed her that it can be accomplished pretty quickly and simply using frameworks like Ruby on Rails or Django. We will likely spend the next few days getting her up to speed and getting the project started so that she can run with it once I leave. Pretty fun stuff!
I also got to work on some other skills such as photography and making movies. I know there is a lot to learn in this space, but for the needs of this community and their businesses, I think this was a pretty good first pass. Take a look at this video I put together for Bodhi Surf School. The video features a group lesson over a few days with Travis, Ronald, and Marlin being the leaders of the pack:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZRVK6I__jI

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Cobb...sounds like your trip is getting off to a solid start. I was working with my group partner Josue and told him you were surfing in Costa Rica. Guess what he did Peace Corps with Travis. He told me to say whats up to him. Peace.

Haha, small world eh! Thanks for checking in dude. You would love it on the beach here. You can work at the hostels and pay nothing to stay there then just mooch food from others. The only price is really getting down here.
Hope you are enjoying your new school bro.
Awesome concept re: philanthropic travel--the talent-sharing aspect sounds particularly brilliant. And the surf looks amazing.
Thanks Erin. I know you have lots to share with the world!

item.title: Mullets, straw bale houses, and thirsty cows
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Warning: this post does not have anything cool about what I have been doing, but instead speaks about things that might make you feel guilty.  I think its interesting though.   “Mullets are a trend, environmentalism shouldn’t be.” – Marshall Fisher It has been an interesting few days full of excitement and strange occurrences.  I will start with a conversion I had with a buddy I met out here, Marshall Fisher.  He majored in Environmental Studies at Western State in Gunnison Colorado.  After a morning surf session, I inquired about his major and one thing let to another, which let us to the topic of straw bale houses.  Here is a snippet from the intertoobs that describes the type of construction: “Straw bale construction has been around since humans first started building shelters.  Its modern day use is a great alternative for those looking for a sustainable solution to home construction.  It will save you 75 percent on heating and cooling costs due to solar gain caused by the wall thickness.  It’s is an excellent form of sound proofing.  Using straw helps to reduce water consumption and air pollution.  It eliminates the need for toxic man made forms of insulation.  It can be used as a load bearing wall and eliminate the need of wood.  It also burns 3 times slower than walls made of wood.”  Source Essentially you can build an entire house out of straw and mud and it is actually way more efficient that the any of the most advanced Leed certified buildings.  When you first think of building a house out of straw, there are probably numerous issues you could immediately identify with this type of construction such as fire, insects, moister, cost, etc…and many of those are answered here: http://www.balewatch.com/questions.html.  When speaking with Marshall I tried to find what the catch was with them, seeing as they are so practical, and the only downsides he could come up with were cost and the social perception associated with people knowing you live in a straw house.  Due to the amount of labor involved, it can actually cost more to construct a SBH than a brick or wood based house.  This would likely balance out after a few years, considering the 60-80% savings you get in energy costs.  Also, if more houses are built in this manner then the technology for creating them will likely advance as well, hopefully bringing down the price. As for the social perception, an impressive part of straw bale houses is that they can make them look really nice, to the point that you wouldn’t know unless someone told you that the house was made of straw: http://www.balewatch.com/dave.interior2.jpg http://www.thestrawbalecottage.com/media/HomePage.jpg http://www.thestrawbalecottage.com/Photos/images/Cox%20West%20Elevation.jpg For me, the benefits of living in such a house go beyond the reduction in environmental impact as I feel that living in such a structure would bring you closer to the earth.  Marshall has been in a few of these houses as they are becoming increasingly popular in Colorado, and he said the feeling you get from walking into one is incredible.  The small of the mud and straw reminds you are part of nature and are indeed embracing it instead of trying to create a structure that separates you from it. Constructing houses from grain agricultures waist products sounds like a great idea to me.  I think I am convinced that if I ever build a house it will be with these materials. My research and sources have been limited on this, so I encourage you to let me know if you find a big “gotcha” associated with straw bale houses. One last item I will discuss on this is that, whenever possible, the way we construct buildings should learn to embrace and not fight the environment around us.  Another interesting part of one of the straw bale houses that Marshall had toured was one in the mountains that had to deal with hot summers and of course, very cold winters with limited light.  The owner used a simple formula to determine where the sun would be during the seasons and placed his windows in a strategic location so that in the summer the overhanging roof would shade the south facing windows for the high sun and in the winter, when the sun has a lower trajectory, the windows would let in all the light of the day.  This allowed for a cooler house in the summer and warmer in the winter.  He was also able to have a garden in the room year round as it got the proper amount of sunlight year round.  Very cool, very simple!   That’s enough of housing construction.  Now, time to harp on another environmental issue.   It takes roughly 2500 gallons of water to produce a pound of meat. I asked Marshall what current energy producing technology he thought was the most sustainable and efficient, and I got an interesting answer.  He said that instead of focusing so much on how to produce more, we should instead be working toward lowering our consumption!  The words of E.F. Schumacher were coming to life in front of me, and the source was a student at an American university in a town that appeared to be trying to embrace these values.  He said that the biggest impact an individual can have today is to watch what you eat.  Many of us have heard this before, and if you watch Food, Inc. you will get an idea of what he is talking about.  One of largest consumers of our natural resources and energy expenders is the process in which food makes it to our tables.  I remember watching this moving and feeling moved and inspired.  Unfortunately, I don’t think I did enough to change my habits based on the main points of the story as much as I should have.  I did try to get a few friends fired up to try eating vegetarian for one day a week, which had some moderate success, but I don’t think any of us kept it up.  For me, it exposed me to something I had never even glanced at before…the vegetarian options on the menu!  To my surprise they often had really interesting options that often ended up tasting better than their meat counterparts.  To name a few in Houston; La Tapatia Taqueria features a veggie burrito stuffed with fresh vegetables and smothered in casa, Little Big’s black bean burgers with some Roster sauce definitely top their meat burgers, Tacos a Go Go’s verde tacos are making my mouth water right now, Les Givral’s tofu Vietnamese sandwiches’ are not the be missed, Nidda Thai’s tofu stir fried flat noodles could keep a man a reason to live.  Unfortunately, many of these dishes are not the healthiest, but they are definitely a nice starting point for eating less meat. Meat is one part of the issue, but the distance of which food travels is likely just as important.  Food often travels thousands of miles, from across the country or across the world.  Whoever can produce the most amount of a crop at the lowest cost is who wins the bid at America’s food manufacturers.  And it is our desire to consume these goods that keeps the wheels going on this process.  It is odd to step back and look at the goods on the shelf and think about how far the food on the shelf had to come, but it is becoming an increasingly important process to follow.  One of the easier ways to start the process might be to get your produce from a local farmers market.  I know, they are often only open early Saturday mornings and feature hippies on hippies, I know.  I know that Saturday morning sucks because you had a big night at Boondocks the night before, but think of how much tastier your homemade veggie fried rice will be, or how much sweeter that mango would be if you got it from a local farmer! Here is a list of farmers markets in the Houston area.  They are all over and at all different times of the week, so try something new this week and check one out! As Food, Inc. reminds us, we vote with every dollar we spend. Marshall and I at the Flutterby House:

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: So, the straw bale houses still have the regular framework but instead of wood/brick/etc siding it's straw? Can it withstand the elements as well as the alternatives and can they last as long? What if the foundation shifts causing cracks in the walls...how is the process of fixing that compared to "regular" houses? I'm intrigued by the idea but skeptical considering you're not likely to get the house insured and probably will have an issue should you want to sell it. Are those real sand dollars in the picture? Awesome!!

From what I can see, it definitely can standup to the elements as its a 18 inch wall. It is probably a lot harder to crack them as well, but I would need to dig around to see if that is the case. Here are some super old straw bale houses. From the sound of it, they are often stronger and last longer than typical building materials. Question 9 talks about permits and loans. It sounds like being the first one in a city/town to do it would take some work to convince them, but I think once the community sees that it can be done and how efficient they are, that it would probably take flight and be easy to sell off. You could definitely get it on a Houston house tour, as it would be a pretty unique home, and that would likely help drive acceptance. And yes, those are real sand dollars! They are everywhere on the beach down here.

Fantastic: http://www.naturalhomeandgarden.com/Homes/2003-07-01/The-Tallest-Little-Straw-Bale-inTexas.aspx The kitchen and the porch are amazing. I feel like there should be deer snuggled up with a bunnies on the porch. Workshops around the world: http://www.strawbaleworkshops.com/ Google tells me that there are plenty of people in Texas moving in the direction of straw bale houses.
Take a close up picture of a sand dollar for me if you can...

Hey Chris, maybe you figured it out already but straw bale houses do not use traditional framing techniques. Entire bales are stacked and can be secured various ways (rebar driven down through the bales or using straps). Whats so cool about stry bale is that, if built right they are very strong and will last hundreds of years if regular maintaince is maintained. I saw a stry bale house in Nebraska that was built in the 1840's and was still suoper solid. Thanks for getting stoked man and keep checking out the newest info on straw bales. They are awesome!

Actually I had to stop all my distracting research on straw bale houses and focus on work/school but I'm really glad you replied about the framing since I was still not sure about that. The whole idea completely blows my mind and when I get more free time I will do far more research. I'll keep you in mind when I get lost in my research since your conversations with Cobb lead to my knowing that these houses even exist. They sound like a perfect fit for a small farm house or lake house. Thanks again for the info!

item.title: Costa Rican Karaoke and Surfing in the Rain
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I have been bouncing around Uvita the last few days and have met some cool folks, tried some new things, and started looking at some new ideas (to me at least). On Saturday night a group from the Flutterby House decided to go out for some Costa Rican karaoke and dancing.  I had been told that ticos take their karaoke seriously and was happy to find that this is pretty true.  When we arrived at the bar/restaurant we found a few people scattered at the bar and at a few tables.  The DJ got things started by playing some chill tico music, which led a few people to the dance floor, but wasn’t making much of a buzz.  Then he opened up the mic to anyone who wanted to flaunt their karaoke skills.  What followed was one of the most impressive and depressing few moments I have had at a bar.  The people and hits of the night were; dude sitting with his girlfriend wailing some slow love song about being with lots of girls but really only wanting one, girl alone at the bar singing a song about needing to find love, birthday bro singing a song about the lack of love in his life, etc.  The local people who sang were incredible, but the songs were so sad and sappy, even in Spanish!  Luckily, karaoke did not last all night.  The DJ try to lift up spirits by bringing on a never ending set of salsa music that was able to get lots of couples on the dance floor.  I danced with our friendly hostel manager, Amy, with whom the decision was made that we need to out due the masters of the dance floor, dude singer and his chica.  They had some very impressive moves I must say, but the rawness from our inexperience made for some interesting dance combos, that I like to think at least made them step up their game a bit.  After that it was on to house music, which brought out the German mother/daughter combo from out hostel to the dance floor.  The mom had so much energy and was going all over the place.  When I complimented her on it, she said something to the effect of “I have been waiting hours for them to stop playing couples tunes and start playing real dance music!”  It was a good session overall. Here is the crew enjoying Imperial's and Pilsons waiting for the music to get going:   I moved to Travis’s the next day as he is out of town and graciously offered to let me house sit and play with his dogs while he was gone.  I have never had pets so it has been interesting to live with two.  I enjoy running with them, but this has translated to them that they should follow me everywhere because who knows, maybe this trip the bathroom might lead to another run!  For the most part they are actually low maintenance and spend most of their time chillin’ on the porch, but you can see it in their eyes that the best day ever would be one in which the running didn’t stop. Yesterday was my Colorado buddies, Tanner and Marshall, last day in town so we were sure to get in a lot of surfing.  We had a good hour-long session at low tide in the morning, which was mostly whitewash riding.  The back break on the beach has been massive the last few days and almost always been a closing break, so there is no chance or reason for even trying to make it past that.  This means that we haven’t had many chances for riding greens (unbroken waves) the last few days, but have had lots of time to work on our standing up technique riding the powerful whitewash from these 15-20ft slammers.  Every 10 minutes or so there is a break in the waves and you can make it out pretty close to the last break, which I went for once.  It was very deceptive because the waves before the calm looked really doable if I could just get past them.  Once they settled, I paddled as quickly as I could out to what I thought was past the break.  After sitting their for 30 seconds I saw a wave quickly forming and before I new it I was 20 ft. away from a monster 20 ft. swell that barreled over and slammed just in front of my board consuming me and sending me summersaulting in the water trying to figure out which way was up.  The wave quickly passed and I was able to make it to the surface with time to spare, but it definitely showed me that it was not even close to worth it to get out there.  Back to the whitewash I went. That afternoon the daily rainstorm came in and didn’t let up.  Marshall and Tanner really wanted to surf, so we went out there to see what it was like surfing in the rain.  It turned out to be one of the coolest and most intense surfing sessions I have had.  It was high tide and the waves were still massive, so we stuck to the whitewash area, but even getting out 100 ft. to each a short ride in was a feat!  Luckily, I found a break in the waves and was able to make it out past the first break.  From there I caught a big wave that had just crashed and got up quickly and watched around me at one of the coolest scenes I had been apart of.  Behind me was the wash from a 15 ft. banger that was propelling me over a patch of waves that appeared to be going in every direction.  Ahead and to the side of me I could see Tanner and Marshall fist pumping at the fact that I actually got on this thing.  On the beach I could see the trees consumed in a mist of rain and clouds.  On my back and head I felt the soothing raindrops of a Costa Rican shower, which did their best to wash the salt off me.  Above you could see the dark clouds as turbulent as the waves below us. I dismounted near the beach, shook of the water, and paddled back out.  It was a great ride shared with some great people.

item.title: New habits, more on surfing, and life in Uvita
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Habits After 3 weeks in the tranquil town that is Uvita, Costa Rica, its time to reflect on those weeks and prepare for the adventures to come. There were several things that I was looking forward to on this leg including starting new habits, learning some Spanish, and learning to surf better. I think I did pretty well for at least two of these. After leaving my job I had 6 weeks to visit friends, which meant lots of good conversation and plenty of drinking. While I do enjoy a good party as much as the next guy, by the end of this stint, not seeing beer didn’t sound like such a bad thing. I know I have said that kind of this before, but this trip was a great opportunity to make a change in that department. I did not seek out opportunities to drink and did not treat every activity as another awesome chance to enjoy a frosty beverage. I know I am probably the most guilty at doing that kind of thing, as many friends will attest to, but there is a time and place for it and I had probably crossed that line a bit. During the last 3 weeks I have enjoyed a few glasses of wine and a few cheeky beers with people I have met, but for the most part I really haven’t partied or overindulged. This allowed for more time and energy to do things like run and surf. I probably would have been able to still do a lot of these things, but by not drinking so much, these things weren’t as difficult to get motivated for. It did mean that I was a lot less social, which I was ok with, considering how much socializing I had done in the previous weeks and years for that matter. I missed several late night excursions to the beach, chances to get to know people more, a Peace Corps party weekend, and even an arts and craft session. The bottom line was that I needed to re-calibrate to a more normal consumption level, so that meant missing a few opportunities, which won’t matter in the long run. I know several friends reading this are saying, “Cobb, you are so ridiculous”, but probably using a little bit more fruity language. Friends, I know. That was one habit that changed, at least temporarily. I also focused on working more without distractions. I stayed at Travis’s house for the last week so I had internet, and since it rained a lot, there was a lot of time to code and/or read. I took this time to finally read a book on Rails, the Rails Cookbook, which gives some solid examples of how to do things like create migrations, use models/controllers/views the Rails way, and do things like authentication. Lots of basic stuff and a few advanced topics, but it finally filled in a lot of gaps in understanding that I had with the framework. I spent two days just looking at the book and not coding much, other than to try a few things it suggested. After that, I spent 3-4 days just working on this sports tracking software side project. I was immediately more productive and when I had new issues was able to find the answer in the book or on stackoverflow. I found that the answers in the cookbook were often better explained and complete. The issue with forums sometimes is that they assume a level of knowledge, which they likely have to, as they don’t want to define the whole context every time you have a problem, but the book walks you through the whole process, which is great for a beginner. So where was the new habit? Well, whenever I am at a computer I get the urge to check my email constantly, browse facebook, and check ESPN for the latest in the sporting world. I looked online for programs that can be used to block sites from yourself, and found that they just update your host file, making remote sites point to your localhost, which blocks them from loading. So I decided I would just update the file manually. I know I could change it, but if I was willing to not go to those sites then I just needed a weak barrier to prevent me from doing so. Sometimes when I am coding and getting frustrated with something not working, I will step aside to check my email for a minute while ignore the problem. This has gotten to be a gut reaction for me, and is definitely not the best way to clear your mind to solve the problem. Thus I updated my host file and when I got the uncontrollable urge to hit cmd+t in Chrome and go to gmail, I would be hit with a welcoming “page not found” message! That was actually enough to tell myself to chill out, and make some tea or something instead of getting frustrated. Then I could think about the problem, come up with better search terms to find some help, and then be able to come up with a solution. It worked for those few days and I hope I can keep it up for future work sessions. I also did a lot more reading on this trip that I normally do. I finished Small is Beautiful, blew through The Sunset Limited, finished Born to Run, learned from the Rails Cookbook, and started The Picture of Dorian Gray. One of my excuses for not reading has often been that I fall asleep easily in the process and then it takes a long time for me to finish a book. Unrightfully and with no evidence, I blame part of it on being read to while going to sleep as a child, but I also read a lot before going to sleep as an adult, which probably had a bigger impact. This trip I read a lot at all times of the day and if I got tired, I would try to do something else, like make tea or walk on the beach to stay awake. I also realize that me staying awake has a lot to do with how much I comprehend in the book. If I am daydreaming a lot then it is hard for me to focus on the story and I quickly loose interest and start to fall asleep. I would try to counter this by trying to clear my mind and focus on the words on the page. Sometimes it would work and other times it wouldn’t. If it didn’t, I would just more on to something else or embrace the nap. But if I could just finish the thoughts and plans running through my head, then I could usually get back to focusing on the book. I also gave meditation a bit of a go, but wasn’t dedicated to it as much as I probably should have been to actually get something out of it. But it’s only the first leg of the trip, so I hope to explore it more. On this trip after running each morning, I would often just lie on my back, eyes closed, and try to clear my mind. It was calming and nice, but I am sure I can get more from it if I put more into it. As far as Spanish goes, I still have a looong way to go. The first week was good as I was exposed to people such as Travis’s neighbors and bus drivers, etc. However, the following week I spent most of my time at a hostel with mostly Americans, so I didn’t get much practice and then just lost motivation to try very hard as I would only be in the country another week. A cop-out I know, but I will do what I can to learn a language at a different point in the trip. The next two months are going to be in English speaking countries anyway. Surfing Then there was surfing. To me, this is one of the toughest sports to pickup. I know a lot of this depends on the beach and conditions, but here is my experience with it. I enjoy extreme sports, but feel that I have been spoiled having snowboarding being my primary sport in this sector. With snowboarding there might be a few day learning curve, but you don’t have to work to get back up the hill after falling all the way down, but with surfing, you do. To begin surfing you will likely ride the broken waves near the beach and just stand up on your long board. This is not too difficult and for most people and can be accomplished on the first day, if not on the first few attempts. For me, that’s cool and all, but I want to go bigger for longer… to be like the good guys on the beach who are effortlessly cutting back and forth on their short boards, carving up the beasts. So riding whitewash is cool, as usually you can walk out to the point where you want to get on your board and ride in without a ton of effort. However, if you want to make it out to the unbroken waves, you are going to have a entire new host of challenges. If you are doing it with a long board then you have to figure out how to get yourself and an 8ft board past 5-10ft waves continually smashing you in the face. You are having salt water blown up your nose and in your eyes and mouth. You are creating an awesome rash on your chest (even if you wear a rash-guard, at least at the beginning) as you are constantly grinding your body again the board as you paddle out. You are being blown off your board as the waves hit, leaving you disoriented, but you have to get back on quick in order to paddle out a little further before the next bomb comes! To me, standing up on the board wasn’t that big of a deal, but getting out past the waves and into a position to do something was very difficult. Even once you are out there, its an art to develop the “surfers eye”, which refers to picking out those 45 degree waves and aligning yourself at the highest point of the incoming wall while identify which way it is going to break so that you can point your board in that direction ahead of time. That means that if you spend 30 minutes paddling out and mistakenly choose a wave that is already too high or maybe that has an even top instead of a peak, then you are going to get crashed on, or immediately closed on, which means no sweet unbroken wave riding for you. And then, you have to paddle back out and try again. So why do people do it? Well, I am still working on that one, but have gotten a little sense of it. I got into a habit of hanging out on my board after paddling out, to catch my breath, but also to take a moment to enjoy the beauty of the ocean and just being out there alone or with friends. I would often only catch a few waves during a session, but would try to be patient and make them good ones, which I had only moderate success with. Also, the conditions of the day and the type of beach really make a difference. We had a solid week of 10-20 footers that really made it tough to get anything done. There were other days when it was a really soft break with lots of gaps in the waves, making it much easier to paddle out. Then of course, there is the satisfaction and excitement of overcoming all of these obstacles. It’s a very cool feeling to be riding sideways on an unbroken wave all the way into the beach. Life in Uvita Rain, rain, rain... Like I said, I did not go out much and actually didn’t take too many opportunities to get to know the people, but did have a few good moments. I spent the last week living at Travis’s, which afforded me the opportunity to get to know his dogs more and his neighbors, including dear Natalia. Natalia liked to pop in and check on my to made sure my vitals where still going. I would run each morning and she always greeted me with an enthusiastic “Hola!” when I returned. She would come over and speak Spanish to me like I was fluent. So I would have my laptop out to translate what I could, but it was pretty difficult to figure things out. Although, I did learn part of a song about a green frog that enjoyed swimming in the river. One morning I cut up a mango and put it in a plastic container to be used for smoothies later, but before I put it up I offered her a piece by handing her the container. Apparently, this means something different in Costa Rica. She took the container to her mouth and proceeded to down the entire diced mango! Mind you, she is 5 years old and quite tiny. No worries, luckily I had another and was still able to make a good smoothie. I also got to know Sugey, the lady of the house a bit. She helps clean Travis’s house so she is in and out each day. I wanted to learn to make rice and beans, so I asked her help me. We made rice together the first day in a rice cooker, and she gave me beans she had made because she said it takes a really long time. She did give me instructions on how to make it, so the next day I mixed beans, water, garlic, and a bunch of spices to make my first batch of rice and beans. I will just say that it was less than amazing. Luckily they have this hot sauce down here called “Lizano”, that can make dirt taste good. I spent the next 4 days enjoying my homemade soil doused in hot sauce! I also made lots of tacos: One of the funniest things I saw on this trip were the dogs trying to swim in the ocean. As expected, the pups have followed me everywhere I go. I had not wanted to take them surfing as I didn’t want them beefing with the other puppies at the Flutterby House, but I decided to take them one day. We get out to the beach without any trouble and they do their typical activities of chasing crabs and birds, and then come chill with me. Once had watched the waves for a bit and decided where I was going to attack, I walked out and was not surprised to see the dogs following me. What I was surprised to see was that they continuing to follow me deep into the waves. They both were trying their best to chase me and Cali was even trying to get on the board. Once they got to the point where some of the waves where crashing, Coco turned back, but Cali, the smaller dog kept doing her best to paddle out there. She got pounded over and over by the waves but insisted on continuing to try. Her little feet were slapping the top of the water and she was frantic to follow me, but finally the depth and waves proved to be too much, and she turned back. After the surf sesh, they met me at the water and walked me back to my stuff. Nice pups. Learning in progress What did I learn on this trip? A few things I learned are that it’s much easier to travel for long periods of time then you might think. I met a 23 year old from Portland who has worked odd jobs throughout his life and has already taken 3 extended bicycle tours, the current one being 11 months from Portland to Costa Rica. He said he just learned Spanish along the way and that farmers have been friendly enough to let him camp on his land. Sounds like a sweet trip to me and he did it on a really small budget. I also feel like I am learning more about minimalism. I am very interested in doing development from the road and found that it was pretty easy on this trip. Knowing that the more I consume the more I will have to work really put things in perspective. By not eating out and not drinking much, my costs were low, so that means only a few hours of billable work would be required each week. It was also really awesome to work only when there was time to work and when the conditions were not right for surfing. This type of flexibility can definitely come from reducing your consumption. Further reading I also started reading one of these each day and trying them if they were interesting: zenhabits.net. This was a decent one: http://zenhabits.net/will/ This is a really cool architect who is interested in creating sustainable projects and helpful projects and areas around the world that need it most: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SCY7eNyAB9I. I love his intensity and that he demands great things from his people, and they deliver.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Sounds awesome Andrew keep up the self exploration! And do yourself and read some Edward Abbey. Maybe give "The monkey wrench gang" or "Desert Solitare" a shot. He has changed my life and maybe you will enjoy also. Pura Vida amigo
