item.title: Bula Fiji
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Written on September 2nd, 2011… I am currently on Mana Island, which is part of a chain of islands off the west coast of the main island in Fiji.  It’s a 45-minute boat ride form Nadi and it’s one of the cheaper islands, as they have very simple dorm rooms to stay in.  I did a bit of snorkeling this morning and saw some schools of fish and a few good size (1-2 ft) tuna.  We got into the Kava last night, which is the Fijian’s muddy alcoholic delight.  It has some very earthy tones and makes your tongue numb at times.  It’s an interesting drink, but you have to down tons of it to get any kind of buzz going, but hey, it’s free!  Beers are $7 out here, so that helps keep the drinking to a minimum. Tuesday was one probably one of the mentally tough days I have had, and it was only the 3rd day into this thing!  I woke up early to catch a ferry out to this island, and the whole time had in my mind that I was getting ripped off.   The islands and activities are surprisingly expensive, but all look really fun.  Things like surfing are $60 for just a few hours.  You can go on fishing trips for $35, but that is probably the cheapest activity.  As I was waiting for my boat I was got scammed into drinking a coconut for $5 and then he wanted more money for beer, but I declined.  Anyhow, that was all fine, but once I got to the island, I met Georgy and Mark from Oxford England who had just come from spending a few weeks in NZ.  They had a terrible time travelling in their camper van as when they tried to park in the towns they would get yelled at by locals.  They were trying to avoid the campgrounds because they said they cost $30-40 a night just to park the car.  They also said that they heard it is going to be crazy expensive during the World Cup.  They heard that campsites were going to be $200 a night and hostels were going to be $50+ a night, not exactly in my budget!  They inquired if I had reservations for when I arrived, and I don’t, which made them frown at me.  They also told me they ran into a lot of people who don’t like backpackers in NZ and that they often got called out for being tourist.   That is not the New Zealand I remember, and not one that I would want to visit!  This really affected me for some reason and made me quite nervous about heading there.  I completely blew it out of proportion in my mind and had thoughts of blowing all my money in the first few months and having to cut my trip short.  I felt that I was in over my head and that since I had not planned much of the trip ahead that I was going to run into lots of problems like this and end up being screwed.  What ridiculous thoughts to have just as I get out to the paradise islands of the pacific! I went running to try to calm down and clear my mind.  I tried to remind myself that this was just these two peoples experience and that I had even been there just a few years before and had not had anything like what they had faced.  Luckily, when I got back from the run I met a few guys who had spent several months on the islands and had no problems at all.  They drove in a car and stayed at POC campsites all over the islands that cost a mere $6 a night.  They said they often didn’t even pay as they really don’t check.  They said the people were friendly and it was easy to get around!  What a different picture they painted from the one that the Oxfordites had brushed.  I appreciate their warning, but think that it will likely be a rough few days at first, but once I setup some couch surfing connections and get my bike, then it should be easy and cheap to get around.  It does help lower my expectations and help me mentally prepare for heckling, in case there is some of that.  Worst case, I can find a cheap campsite and just stay there for an extended amount of time, but I really don’t think that will be necessary.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Get your update on, bro. Where are you?

item.title: First couch surfing experience
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This video shows many of the stories listed below, so you might want to read it first. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXrcKtOOhnU Just got back from 5 days on Mana Island, which is indeed paradise!  Hmm, where to begin on the weeks adventures...how about Barara.  Just before coming out to Fiji I finally signed up for couchsurfing.com, which if you don’t know, connects travelers with locals who are willing to provide a place to crash for nothing but good conversation.  I ended up getting a bed with Save, a Fijian with a house near Nadi.  He has a full house just with his family and often has a few couch surfers hanging around.  He currently provides a roof for his niece, nephew, daughter, two sons, wife, and the wife’s sister.  I got to know Coby, the nephew pretty well, as Save signed him up as my tour guide. I landed at 5am on Tuesday and Coby was there to greet me with a sign that proudly displayed “Andrew Cobb”!  Haha, I have never had a sign for me at an airport and was very surprised that my first one would be through a couch surfing connection.  We took a cab to the house and slept for a few more hours.  At breakfast, the family tends to eat in waves and the conversation was slightly sparse.  They mainly spoke in Fijian, but they do know English.  It was also strange to me that Save did not introduce his family, but from what I have heard from a few others, this isn’t entirely uncommon in Fiji.  We enjoyed boiled root for breakfast with a side of tea.  Save believes that every meal should be served with tea, which I am definitely ok with!  So it was a bit of an awkward breakfast, but things definitely got a lot better. During the day, Coby took me out to the Garden of the Sleeping Giant’s where we checked out lots of orchids and wild flowers.  It was a bit of a tourist trap, but ended up being nice because I could visit with Coby.  After we saw the flowers we headed to the local farm to get some veggies for dinner.  I thought we would be going to meet with the farmer or going to a market to buy some fresh vegetables, but it turned out that what we were seeking was free.  There were small leafy plants that grew in between the large crops on the farm that were considered more of a nuisance to the farmer, but are really good eating if you collect a bunch of them.  We gathered them over the next hour while Coby told me all about his schoolwork, love life, and rugby skills.  He is currently in high school and wanted to be a pilot so that we can see the world.  He wants to go to Rotorua Boys’ High School in New Zealand next year, as it will be a chance to get off the islands for a bit and practice more English.  He is very well spoken and his English is already good as we are learning it in school and practices with all the couch surfers that Save has around.  He is a captain at his school which means that when the teacher is away or if they are having study hall or something, then he is in charge of the students to ensure that things to not get out of hand.  He sounded like he was fair but stern with his peers and got a lot of respect for it.  It sounds like he will be a great success if he keeps at it. That night they prepared the freshly picked plants and mixed them with an awesome coconut sauce.  All it had was lemon, coconut milk, diced pepper, and chopped onion, but was incredibly refreshing and delightful. The next day I had to take care of my credit cards as I got declined at the duty free shop upon arrival.  Save wanted me to pickup some rum for his birthday and luckily I had enough cash to pay for it, as my cards weren’t working.  It turned out that there wasn’t really a problem at all.  When I called the CC company they said there already was a travel warning and that there was no record of the card being declined.  So I went to the ATM and grocery store and used them both without a problem.  I guess the lesson there is to try the card at more than one store before getting frantic. I went running after that mess and then met up with Coby in the afternoon.  We had met a few local kids the night before and they said they could take me up to mountain to some man made pools.  We hoped over to their village and met them with their machetes and huge rubber boots.  Before we went out on the hike they chopped up some sugar cane and said that we will need the sweet Fijian juice to give us energy to make it up the hill.  I took a bite into the cane and the juice went flying everywhere.  It was sweet, but not too sweet, and really quenching in the Fijian sun.  While enjoying the cane they told me more about the pools and warned me that if I see a cow coming for me I need to run like hell or get up a tree, so they don’t mess around.  Literally 15 minutes later we came across 20 cows on the trail and they were not happy to see us.  Robert and Ropate threw rocks at them and yelled, but this had little effect as they quickly organized themselves by gathering and started heading toward us.  Coby and I went for a tree that was hanging over a small stream and I turned on my camera to catch the action.  R and R spent a few more minutes trying to scare the beasts off, but did not have any success, so we ended up using the tree as a jumping off point to reach the other side.  Of course there ended up being even more cows on the other side, but they were not as interested in starting a fight, so we were able to make it into the jungle.  Once in the woods, we hung out for a bit and ate some fallen fruit that I found to be quite bitter and a little unpleasant.  However, I ate about 15 of them, not wanting to disappoint my tour guides. After a good rest and a full stomach, we headed down to the pools.  The main pool was 25ft across, muddy, and pretty dern cold.  It was at this pool that we shot a MTV cribs style video with Ropate, playing the role of 50-cent, showing off his “infinity pool” and his gangsteresk mannerisms.  It was a site to be seen, and we all got a great laugh out of it!  Checkout the video above for a look at the pool! On the way back to the house, we stopped off at the local recreation field to see if we might be able to get in on a touch rugby game.  Rugby is definitely the national sport here as all the villagers play from very young to middle age.  Everywhere I went, if I saw local people hanging out, they were usually tossing a ball around or playing a pickup game.  So, as expected, there were a few people out on the field tossing the ball around.  Within 20 minutes the number of players grew from 5 up to roughly 40 players.  Kids and adults were coming out of the woodwork to get in their daily rugby fix.  The field was about 100 yards long and 40 yards wide, and there were enough players to stretch from sideline to sideline. I was the only Caucasian out on the field and definitely looks like the noob I am as I dropped passed and nearly caused interceptions with my poor passing.  Many of the players greeted me with warm smiles and introduced themselves when they were playing close to me.  Being the only white guy out there didn’t feel strange at all either, as no one appeared to mind me joining, and actually I think they enjoyed watching me since I was such a beginner at the sport.  Before the game, I told Coby that I was going to smoke him on the field and score 10+ trys, trying to get a rise out of him. After making a fool of myself for the first hour, I kept to the back of the line so that I wouldn’t interfere with the playing, and because I was exhausted from the day’s activities.  The guys on my team appeared to notice this and tried to get my back in it by giving me easy passes and being available to catch it again quickly.  On one of these gentle passes, I noticed that I had a gap up in front of me.  I think the defense was playing off me a bit, as I really wasn’t contributing much.  I took this opportunity to blast threw to line and make a run for the try line!  When I looked behind me, who else but Kobe was hot on the pursuit!  We darted down the unmarked overgrown field as my teammates were screaming, “Run! Run! Run!”  Just as I neared the end of the field, Coby reached out and tagged me!  Coby claims that he definitely got me before the end zone, but since there were not any lines, I really don’t know.  It doesn’t matter though as the jury of both sides decided that my efforts were good enough to call a try!  Man, what a cool feeling to be playing rugby at sunset with tons of friendly Fijians and actually getting to score! Another interesting part of the pickup game was how chill everyone was.  No one got upset about fouls or dropped balls and everyone was constantly heckling each other in a very friendly and joyful way.  It was all smiles and laughs as no one tried to be the superstar and no one was left out of the action. After the game we went down to the bus stop to get some more sugar cane and to meet some more of the teenagers of Barara.  I had my camera with me and asked the guys to pose with their machetes and cane sticks!  They jumped at the opportunity and went on to hold their own photo-shoot for the next 30 minutes.  Many of them have facebook, but don’t have cameras in order to get a profile picture, so all of them took individual mug shots so that I could upload them and tag them.  They really enjoyed this activity and I look forward to friending them!  You can checkout my “Making friends in Fiji” album on facebook for the pics. The kids were all too familiar with American movies and could quote most of them.  They also get a lot of top-40 music on the bus so they, or at least Coby, is always serenading you with the latest from Eminem and Justin Beiber.  The guys spoke very fondly of Fiji and wanted to make sure that I was really enjoying my time, which I definitely was.  Most of them actually expressed interest in travelling the world as well, but said that the Fijian dollar makes that very difficult for them to do.  Hopefully the kids will keep doing well in school and get opportunities to work or travel as they wish.

item.title: Mana Island, Fiji. Met Moses and the 3 wise Englishmen
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: [gallery] Save, my couch surfing host, is a travel consultant and set me up with a 5-day trip out to Mana Island.  The island is 45 minutes from the main island and located within eyesight of the Tom Hanks film, Castaway.  The island features white sand beaches, palm trees, a few gentle hills, is surrounded by coral, and has accommodations ranging from dorm style living to 6-star resorts.   I stayed at Serena Backpackers, which is run by the people of the village on the island.  They were incredibly welcoming and took care of our every whim and need.  As Mark said, my new Oxford buddy, if you don’t like a meal then tell “mum” that and she will make it better next time.  All meals were included in the package and the food was actually really good and didn’t require any special requests from me.  We had pancakes or biscuits for breakfast, pizza mash or sandwiches for lunch, and stew’s and stir fry’s for dinner.  Food has not been hard to finish in Fiji! There are 2 backpackers right next to each other on the island and they are quite different in nature.  Serena is very laid back and doesn’t have a ton of activities, but has really great staff.  Next door also has great staff, but is much more geared towards the party crowd.  They were up until sunrise almost every night drinking Kava, having cross dressing parties, doing karaoke, and dancing up a storm!  You could hear them all night, so if you didn’t have earplugs, you were definitely in for a fun night.  Funny how only a month ago I would have definitely wanted to stay there instead. Fiji is an interesting destination for backpackers because it is often the beginning or the end of people’s travels.  Many folks are either coming from Southeast Asia and Australia/New Zealand and headed back to Europe, or are just getting started and heading to those same places.  It is fun because you get to hear all the stories and recommendations from people who just spend half a year in the places you are dying to see.  Some of the interesting people I met with Mark and Georgy from Oxford, Gudrun and Jakob from Austria, and Toby from London. Mark and I passed the time by trying out each other’s accents and speaking about the many differences in our cultures.  His favorite was when I would call dinner rolls biscuits instead of rolls.  Biscuits are with tea, he would proclaim!  Georgy was his girlfriend who was frantically working on her tan before having to head back to cloudy and cold England.  They both were very home sick after being on the road for 5 months.  They said they actually were looking forward to and enjoy England winters, as it is a chance to hibernate at home or in a pub!  Georgy is wrapping up school and probably going to help take over Mark’s mom’s B&B.  Mark is a 24-year-old antique furniture restorer, who is apparently very good at what he does.  He says that a typical day for him might be listening to drum-n-base in his workshop in the morning, going dirt biking on his 450cc monster in the afternoon, and then hitting the clubs of Oxford at night.  A very interesting lifestyle for a craftsman! Gudrun and Jakob are just getting started and are going to many places that I will be hitting as well.  Jakob is a big snowboarder and is actually pretty dern good.  His biggest trick is a cork 7, which is a flipping, twisting 720 degree rotation.  Very impressive stuff.  Gudrun is all smiles and loves playing cards.  They invited me to stay with them once I get to Austria so that we can snowboard and eat Austrian dumplings! Toby has spent 5 months on the road with friends and doing the common route, but is also headed to South America for a few months.  Very interesting and chill kid who loved to sleep. On the last night, I went fishing with the man with the world famous laugh, Moses.  He does two trips a day depending on demand and takes you around the islands to catch tuna and barracuda.  Several people from our hostel had done it and said it was a riot.  I got the chance to go with Mark, and three other guys from England.  It was a really windy day, but Moses assured us that we would catch a lot as he knew the secret spots and that the weather would be good there.  We ended up trolling for 3 hours at sunset and only catching a 16-inch barracuda!  That really didn’t matter because it was the most entertaining fishing trip I have been on.  The English guys were very conversational and the sunset off in the distance made for great atmosphere.   Every 15 minutes Moses would notify us that it was just reaching “striking time” and that the fish would soon be jumping into the boat.  That never happened and at the end of the ride he said “Well, that is fishing.   The weather was not good and just like anywhere in the world, fish hide during the storm.”  Haha, man, what a 180 on his comments before the ride!  Reminds me of that Chappelle Show interview with Rick James!  It was a great trip non-the less, and I would happily do it again. The next morning I met with Moses to help him get an email account.  Turns out that the intertoobs were down on the whole island.  So, instead of setting that up, we decided on an email (mosesfishingmanaisland@gmail.com) and password, so that I could set it up when I got to the main land.  He also wanted me to send him a post card confirming the action, but I told him that he just needed to check in a day or two and it would be up.  It is up, so give him a shout if you want to fish in Fiji! Books finished: The Picture of Dorian Gray The Sunset Limited

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This is the first time I have checked out your blog since you started it. Already regretting it as the jealousy courses through every fiber of my 9-5 being, haha. Just kidding man it sounds like you are having a great time. Also, I can't believe you finished The Picture of Dorian Gray. When you get back we can discuss literature and be super classy while throwing back some Lonestar tall boys.

Haha, thanks man. It's a bit lonely at times out here, but it is an adventure! Would love to have you out.
Yeah, it was a very interesting read. It would be hilarious to have a snotty high ball glass night and only speak of beauty and finer things, not peasants and tragedies.

item.title: Bastrop, TX Wildfires
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Friends, For 7 of the past 11 years I have ridden bike ride from Houston to Austin.  The ride helps raise money for multiple sclerosis and does a great job at it.  The highlight of this ride for me is always the hills of Bastrop State Park.  They are some of the steepest paved rodes in Texas and provide endless joy.  You pound the peddles as you asend the monsters, but they its sheer bliss and you reach speeds of 35-40 miles and hour riding down them. It appears that the park and area around it now now either in flames or will be soon.  My friend from work Geoffrey Schiffli sent me this picture: Here is the whole note from Geoffrey: ------------------------------------ All, There is a crazy fire in Bastrop, and it’s affecting Bastrop State Park.  If you’re still wondering why you’re getting this e-mail, you didn’t take the challenge route during the MS150 through Bastrop.  Over 50% of the state park has burned, and the fire is still 0% contained (been going on for 2 days).  The picture below is from the park.  I live nearby (about 30 miles) from Bastrop, and am going to make a run up there tomorrow night to drop off money/supplies for whoever needs it. If you’d like, you can send me money via PayPal to (contact me for his email) and I will use it to get more supplies. Please forward this on to anyone else who may be interested in giving.  Please do not send after tomorrow afternoon. Thanks, Geoffrey ------------------------------------ I sent funds from New Zealand and hope you can help out as well, even if it just enough to get a few cold beers for the fire fighters. Keep the families of the area in your thoughts.

item.title: Bicycling across New Zealand for the Rugby World Cup
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I purchased the bike from a second hand shop in Auckland, which can be found at www.thesecondhandbikeshop.com.  The young guy helping me was very friendly and patient with me, as I didn’t really know what I wanted or where I wanted to go.  He said a guy had brought it in just a few days before who used it back in the early 90’s to tour the country.  The bike was in good condition came fully loaded for hitting the road with: 1989 Chromoly 500 Double Butted: Motorized head and taillight 3 pannier bags Extra lights Tube repair kit Pump that didn’t work The original owners manual: The original receipt: The new receipt: Schedule for September: Attend the opening match for the 2011 Rugby World Cup in Auckland.  The game will feature the hosts and favorites, The All Blacks, against their island rivals Tonga! 255 mile 5-day route from downtown Auckland to New Plymouth [googlemaps http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&source=s_d&saddr=Nelson+St&daddr=River+Rd+to:Ohautira+Rd+to:Waitomo+Caves+Rd+to:State+Hwy+to:Leach+St&hl=en&geocode=Fd6szf0dt5dqCg%3BFYkex_0dxV9tCg%3BFUXpvv0doOltCg%3BFT0iuP0drU1wCg%3BFXfFsf0dHXdoCg%3BFdgKrP0dkFBgCg&dirflg=h&doflg=ptm&mra=ls&ie=UTF8&vpsrc=0&ll=-37.952861,174.649658&spn=2.936599,4.438477&output=embed&w=425&h=350] Attend USA vs. Russia in New Plymouth.  These are two low seeded teams that would love to get any kind of win.  Hopefully the USA can pull it out! 257 mile 3-day route from New Plymouth to Napier [googlemaps http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&source=s_d&saddr=New+Plymouth,+Taranaki,+New+Zealand&daddr=-39.81476,174.81516+to:State+Hwy+to:State+Hwy+to:Napier,+Hawke's+Bay,+New+Zealand&hl=en&geocode=FfcOrP0dXC1gCikNzmQj5vkUbTGg6aJDYe8ABQ%3BFZh5oP0duHdrCik_7wkwBVcVbTEw4f8GYe8AEw%3BFUmanf0dA9VwCg%3BFStOnf0dKp-BCg%3BFRRjpf0dknaLCimZyrFP1slpbTFQ6KJDYe8ABQ&sll=-39.986328,176.316833&sspn=0.161778,0.276375&vpsrc=6&dirflg=h&doflg=ptm&mra=mi&mrsp=3&sz=12&via=1&ie=UTF8&ll=-39.664914,176.481628&spn=1.28971,2.210999&output=embed&w=425&h=350] Attend Canada vs. France in Napier.  France is a very strong team and is considered a contender for the final four.  Canada would be looking to make a huge upset! 205 mile 4-day route from New Plymouth to Wellington [googlemaps http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&source=s_d&saddr=Napier,+Hawke's+Bay,+New+Zealand&daddr=Highway+50+to:State+Hwy+to:High+St+to:Wellington,+New+Zealand&hl=en&geocode=FRRjpf0dknaLCimZyrFP1slpbTFQ6KJDYe8ABQ%3BFSson_0dXO-DCg%3BFT88l_0dF3Z7Cg%3BFaz0jv0dZKF3Cg%3BFTLtif0d89NqCinLdOlJ_LE4bTFwtBOiY-8ACg&sll=-40.925446,175.671043&sspn=0.158235,0.276375&vpsrc=6&dirflg=h&doflg=ptm&mra=mi&mrsp=3&sz=12&ie=UTF8&ll=-40.371659,175.946045&spn=2.552801,4.421997&output=embed&w=425&h=350] Attend Australia vs. USA in Wellington.  Australia is part of the Tri-Nations, which are 3 of the best teams in the sport.  They will be heavy favorites and fun to watch against our scrappy squad. Where will I stay? I plan on doing Couch Surfing and Freedom Camping along the route.  Freedom Camping is a great tradition in New Zealand but it is under heavy criticism as many backpackers have abused the privilege, leaving polluted campsites and waterways as well as grumpy locals.  I will have to watch my P’s and Q’s to make sure I don’t get on some farmers bad side. http://www.doc.govt.nz/parks-and-recreation/places-to-stay/freedom-camping/ http://www.tourism.net.nz/new-zealand/about-new-zealand/free-camping.html I also plan on routing for England as its cliché to route for NZ, the USA doesn’t have a chance, and my ancestors came from Kent, England!  Hopefully I can get a rise out of some of the locals! Lets go, bloody Englishmen!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Don't kill yourself, NZ is a lot more hilly than houston. Looks like fun.
This is way more true that I had hoped!

item.title: Biking, the hard way
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[gallery link="file"]
Day 1
Woke up early after a fun night of going to the opening match of the Rugby World Cup! The game did not feature the best play, but it was awesome to see the haka from the 4<sup>th</sup> row and be part of all the fan-fair of the opening game!
I packed my bike up and headed out from Thang’s apartment near downtown Auckland. I had anticipated there being a lot of problems getting out of the city as I hear NZ drivers aren’t the friendliest. I actually had no problem getting out of town! They have big bike lanes for most of the route and I saw a lot of other bikers out there (minus 50lbs of bags, of course). It was smooth sailing down to Pukekohe, where I made it in time for the farmers market. Most of the places were closing up, but I managed to find a corn dog stand that was still open. Very tasty after a 30 mile ride!
I headed south from there, and just after the last town for 60 miles, my bike managed to break. The front shifter gave out, which prevents me from getting and maintaining speed out of hills. I went back into town and tried to fix it, but had no luck. It was not a critical issue, so I pushed on.
After Tuakau there is a big river and then a massive 2-3 mile hill coming out of the valley. That pretty much killed me, so I stopped off at a gate where I saw two people tending to their cows. I spoke with Trish who said they really didn’t have room as the cows roam all of their land, but then Ross came over and said “sure bro, I have just the spot for you!” He took me down to his “happy place” where he has “watches the world go by” ever since we was a kid. It’s a few acres of tress right in the middle of his land that features stunning views of the surrounding hills, nice tall tree coverage, a stream, waterfall, and plenty of room to setup a tent!
On my way down to the bush, my back tire got smashed on a rock and I got a flat. Ross felt terrible about it, but it really was no bother, as I was getting a place to stay and he had the tools I needed to get back in shape. He put my bags and me on his dirt bike and we rode the rest of the way without an issue. He dropped me off and said if time allowed he would be back to show me around.
He did come back and took me to the stream nearby while it was starting to get dark. He wanted to show me New Zealand’s famous glowworms! Right on his property! What a piece of land Ross and Trish have.
I slept that night without a problem. He picked me up in the morning and took me on a tour of his land. He pointed out the bush that lines his 250 acres of land. Then we went to his anger management area, which is a bunch of rocks and boulders that he digs up and breaks down to sell to the towns. Just beyond the boulder garden is a 60ft waterfall! He says he likes to say it in feet, because it sounds better than 20 meters, what a character.
Day 2
We got my bike sorted and I was on my way out right as the rain started. I needed to cover 40-50 miles that day and without 2 of my biggest gears, it was going to be a lot of fun in the rain. By 11am I had made pretty good progress, but was getting pretty tired. I stopped for water and lunch, and within 10 minutes, I was too cold to sit around, so I gobbled my sandwich and headed onward.
I stopped a few times in the afternoon to adjust my bags and get water. It was a lot nicer as the sun has come out for a bit. I also decided to reorganize things, so I tossed a few more things in my bag and then decided to give up my lovely straw hat! It had gotten mangled in the ride from me leaning the bike over on it and the rain soaking it. I left it on a signpost, so maybe some lucky kid will get it and try to fix it.
Around 2pm, I was getting really tired of the massive hills and the rain was really coming down. I decided to call it a day. I pulled off to a house and asked if I could pitch a tent. They said that no one lives in the house next door, so I could setup wherever over there. It ended up working out pretty well as there was an old small garage that had enough room for me to dry things and setup my tent. My hosts never came to speak with me, so I left the next day without getting to know them.
Day 3
About 10 miles into the next days ride, I hit a massive hill and then my rear shifter went out! Now I have 2 done shifters, and rain and wind in my face. I parked it on the side of the hill and decided to hitch it. Within 5 minutes I had my bike in the back of a truck and I was headed to Hamilton on the fast track!
They were nice enough to drop me at the bike store where they fixed my shifters in less than 60 seconds. The screws on the shifters just needed to be tightened! Damn, that would have saved me some trouble. I decided to go ahead and get new tires, since the ones on there were very thin. I figured with 2 months to go on this thing; I shouldn’t take any chances early.
I found a backpacker in town that had the best hot shower I have had since I started the trip! They also had cheap Internet, so I was able to make some adjustments to my plan. I decided to cut out Napier because it snowed over the central flatlands yesterday and it was over 60-100 miles of riding a day. Unfortunately, that is too much for me at this point! The hills and weather wear on me quickly.
I am hoping to get to New Plymouth still by Thursday night, which is a long shot, but I have a place to stay midway and once I get to NP, so all I need to worry about is putting one pedal in front of the other.
The first night I have a place to stay in Piopio (63 miles) and it sounds like if I can make it to Te Kuiti (50 miles) then he could probably pick me up. I will be staying with William, who has a spear bedroom at his farmhouse. He claims to be very messy, but clean enough not to get sick. Should be a character, I am sure.
From there, its 85 miles onto New Plymouth. That is going to probably be too much to ride, so I am hoping to hitch for the bit that I can’t make. The game is at 7:30pm, so I hope I can make it in time for that. If not, it’s not a huge deal. I am going to be staying with a couple that appear to be very interesting, so it should be fun to stay with them, regardless of if I make the game. Although it would be disappointing if I miss it by a few hours!
I am currently staying with David, a couch surfer in his 60s. He loves to travel, and figures it’s his turn to repay the favors he has received! He has a beautiful house just outside Hamilton with a large garden where he has 26 different fruit trees! He left me here for the day to fix the Internet and do whatever else I need to do. He just got back from 5 weeks in Russia where he traveled on the fly and with couch surfers and had an absolute blast! Dad, are you listening?
Now that I am back in the city, I have lost control of my eating! I have eaten 6 meat pies and a bag of cookies in the last 24 hours, because they are delicious and I did not eat much the previous days! It sure is hard to control oneself when things are on sale.
Anyhow, off to other chores. More to come.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
If the Blue Marauder breaks down again in the late Spring heat of NZ, thought a few words from lovely Dallas might be helpful - 8:42 pm, 100 degrees after a high of 107, high micro-climate humidity at the Brown house after main water line to the house broke in the front yard, need to fill in resulting crater this weekend, resod (or just sod it), 104 forecast for tomorrow.
I sent your blog address this morning to John Panning of Dobson Pipe Organ Builders in Lake City, Iowa. (Town motto: Everything But A Lake). He is an avid bike rider, master of your Dad's favorite website "Prairie School Traveller", and the Tonal Director for the builder of the new pipe organ at our church. Interesting guy.
That does help Johnny! I have burrowed into a house in Hamilton and could definitely use some motivational words to get me back on the trail!

Oops! Guess it's really late Winter in NZ. I seem to have skipped a season trying to move Dallas immediately to winter weather here!
Enjoying your blog.

item.title: Plans? We don’t need no stinkin ‘plans
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Looking at my last post few posts you would see that I was planning to be much further south by now, but things happen and you just go with it! I am currently in Awakino, which is on the west coast 52 miles north of New Plymouth. I am staying at Seabreeze campground in my lovely TarpTent, enjoying tea and soaking up the rare sunny day! After my first two days of biking, I realized it was going to be pretty miserable to continue at a heavy pace as it’s just getting to spring time and there is lots of rain, wind, and cold weather. The current approach is to stay with people when I can for a few days at a time and then wait for decent weather before hitting the road. This means I am probably not going to attend anymore RWC games, but the tradeoff so far has felt more rewarding. I spent 4 days couch surfing with David in Hamilton. He is a guy who has been travelling on and off for 40+ years, has been married and had kids, and has opinions on most every topic! He was a joy to stay with, as I was left to my own devices during the day and when he got home we would have 3-4 hour dinners sharing stories and discussing ideas. Some of my favorites were: • 2 walnuts, 2 brazil nuts, and 2 cocoa nuts per day will provide you a very healthy body • Don’t make plans when travelling. Fly in early to give yourself a day to find a place to stay. Then figure it out as you go! Sometimes you might have to pay more, but more often you will find people to put you up or take you on trips that will lead to a more diverse and interesting trip! • Never say, “I don’t like”. By saying this you are limiting your options and spreading negative thoughts within and around you. Find the beauty in everything or just learn to live with whatever it is. By saying “I don’t like” you are restricting your options on the road and preventing yourself from a possible great experience! • New Zealand libraries have free internet! • How to can fruit in 2.5 minutes • Awesome tea: zealong.com • Tourist need to be shown, travelers can see it. • Write poetry while travelling. When you scale a mountain or find a waterfall, write something in that moment! You will appreciate it later. • Trying to write about thoughts days later doesn’t work because you are that many days older and wiser! • When changing diets, don’t think that the impact will come immediately. For instance, if you are becoming a vegetarian, your body will need time to adjust to the veggies and learn to process the good things out of them. If a vegetarian were to eat meat, they might get sick, so it takes time for the body to adjust to process new foods. • Good things to eat: turmeric (colors rice and adds flavor), flax oil (sweetener replacement) • Good travelling food: rice in a bag with tuna mixed in. Don’t forget to add greens! • Always look to the future as looking at the past is living in the past. People can become depressed by focusing on the rough road they came down instead of looking toward a bright future. • He runs an IT department at a large firm and insists that his workers are only there from 9am-3pm. He has one lady working for him who can’t handle these hours, so she comes in from 8am-5pm because that is what she is used to! • When the workload increases, hire more people, don’t work your people harder. So that was a lot of what we discussed. It was great getting to know David, and I would suggest you try to meet him if you are ever in Hamilton! [caption id="attachment_141" align="aligncenter" width="224" caption="Veggies on Veggies"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_142" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="David and his undies after several months of travel in Greece"][/caption] After that odyssey of the mind and palette, I headed on to Piopio. There I met William, a sheep and cattle farmer who loves hosting people to help work or just to visit. I actually met him in Te Kuiti at a cattle auction just outside of town. Unfortunately, I was 15 minutes late to see an auction, but did get a chance to watch the sold cattle being loaded up and I walked about the stadium-seating venue where the auctions take place. Pretty interesting place to see dozens of steer being shuffled around and the auction venue was pretty nice. After doing a few errands in town, we headed to Piopio to his farm. As he admits, he is not the tidiest person, but his home is quite cozy. He was a log fireplace that keeps the house toasty and several guest rooms to provide space you travelers and relatives. While I was there, a Canadian names Edward started his two-week stint on the farm. He has been teaching English on and off in Korea for the past few years and was on the farm to try being a shepherd as he didn’t he “doesn’t like work” and things that it could be a pretty chill gig. After a few days on the farm, I don’t know that chill is how we would describe it, but it is a bit therapeutic, although hectic at times. It is the season for the sheep to give berth, so we saw lambs taking their first steps as well as lambs dying due to complications during or right after birth. The therapeutic time for me was herding them down the back roads of Piopio, watching them hunt of grass while constantly keeping an eye on what the humans were doing behind them. It gives you lots of time to think, as you must be patient with 100+ pregnant sheep! William fed us very well, having tasty meals of mashed potatoes, stew, casserole, and on the last day, hokey pokey ice cream! Again, I found myself eating as much as I could fit in my stomach! I find that if the food is on my plate, then it will get eaten. When I am out on the bike, I know I have to ration things, so I eat a lot less. But when my host provides a feast, I feast! I will definitely need to work on that. It was a great experience living on a farm for a few days. I got to herd sheep and steer, fix Williams computer, run a bit, and talk about life with William, his brother, and Edward. William had great stories of being a fisherman in his younger days when he sailed around New Zealand, parts of Australia and even up to San Diego, California. He is a passionate guy who loves to laugh and tell stories. His brother was very much into American politics and had lots of ideas and theories to share with me that were quite interesting. It is amazing to see how much American politics are discussed around the world, but in America we barely talk about other countries. A quick side note is that I watched Al Jazera a bit while at David’s and was really impressed with the coverage. It was a bit eye opening to see all the news of conflicts around the world, many that I had never even heard of. They still covered things like the Tea Party Republican Convention, but that was only one of many different topics and countries covered! Edward played excellent guitar and is into older country and bluegrass. It was great having someone my age to discuss the experiences of the farm and to learn about Korea and Canada from him! He was fascinated with North Korea and had lots of stories to relate to us on it. Such as; you can only enter from China and you have to pay a few thousand dollars to have them give you a heavily staged tour; there is a movie about helping a North Korean escape only to have the girl want to go back as she needs to support her leader/god; the threats of NK are mostly ignored by the South Koreans, but if there is any kind of attack, then there of course is lots of discussion. Not sure where I am going next and I won’t try to look to far in advance. Might stick around here another day or head onto New Plymouth to stay with another couch surfer. Stay positive and keep looking forward! [caption id="attachment_149" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Piopio farm day 4: feeding the steer in style"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_151" align="aligncenter" width="224" caption="Hokey Pokey in my tea and porridge - I love this stuff!"][/caption]

item.title: Masterton Marathon Training
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I have not written about this much, but I am planning on doing a marathon in Masterton (near Wellington) on October 9<sup>th</sup>! I started training about 5 weeks ago in Uvita and have been running almost everyday since. Some of the more interesting runs:
- Running 12 miles barefoot on the beach in Costa Rica with Travis’s dogs
- Running 8 miles through the massive hills of Boulder, Colorado in pink aqua socks
- Running 16 miles on a 4 mile island (Mana Island) in Fiji
- Running 14 miles around the farms near William Toms farm in Piopio
Most of my training has been on beaches, so I have been trying to run barefoot when possible. When I run on concrete I either use trail runners or those aqua socks.
I read online that Target aqua socks are a poor mans vibrums. I have really enjoyed running with them as they are lightweight, breath well, but have enough sole to protect from sharp rocks and glass. Unfortunately, they are falling apart, so I hope to find new ones before the race. Not the most durable things in the world, but they did survive maybe a hundred miles of running.
It has been a real challenge to keep up with the running while biking, but since I have slowed down the biking pace, it has been a bit better. I have a 20 miler this weekend that is going to be fun. I definitely won’t be biking that day!

item.title: There is Joy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[gallery]
There is joy in the city where comforts of homes are shared. There is joy on the farm where one respects the land and lives by it. There is joy on the street as sheep meander to their new home. There is joy in a tent where one learns to appreciate the subtleties of life. There is joy on the bike where hills become mountains, rain becomes refreshing, wind becomes your challenger, sun becomes your escape. There is joy in the pub where people exchange laughs and stories. There is joy at the game where children discover their hero’s. There is joy in change remembering that to be infinite is to desire it.
Written sitting at a café in Mokau, New Zealand after a breakfast of a whitebait fritter, a Hawaiian burger, and cup of tea.
Quotes from Finite and Infinite Games:
• So, too, with those who look everywhere for difference, who see the earth as source, who celebrate the genius in others, who are not prepared against but for surprise. “I have traveled far in Concord” (Thoreau). • Genuine travel has no destination. Travelers do not go somewhere, but constantly discover they are somewhere else. • A garden is a place where growth is found. It has its own source of change. One does not bring change to a garden, but comes to a garden prepared for change, and therefore prepared to change. It is possible to deal with growth only out of growth. True parents do not see to it that their children grow in a particular way, according to a preferred pattern or scripted stages, but they see to it that they grow with their children. The character of one’s parenting, if it is genuinely dramatic, must be constantly altered from within as the children change from within. So too, with teaching, or working with, or loving each other.

item.title: Biking madness and friendly locals
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
It has been a very eventful few weeks with lots of interaction with locals and travellers.
Two weeks ago I started the trip from the farm in Piopio over the hills down the coast to New Plymouth. It took 4 days of biking from Auckland to make it to the coast at Mokau, and it was worth it! Arriving on the coast, I found a nice campground on the coast with a nearby pub. The campground in Awakino was known for harboring travelling kiwi’s that love fishing for whitebait, which is a mino type fish that goes well with fritters. I had a whitebait fritter at the local coffee shop and thought it was all right. It was not something I was craving at the time. While enjoying my tea and fritter a group of construction workers came in and ate at least two burgers a piece with fries and donuts. This broke my burger free record for the trip, as I had to have one after smelling them. I went for the kiwi Hawaiian burger, which comes with a patty, special sauce, lettuce, tomato, ham, pineapple, and beetroot. Ooooohhh doggy was that baby good, but at what cost? I didn’t think one burger would set me off, but in a way it did. I will cover that in a bit though.
I biked to the pub to watch the rugby and enjoyed some fries and a beer, as the sun was setting in Awakino. What I did not realize was that there were no streetlights on the 3km road from the campsite to the pub. I have those motorized lights on my bike, but did not test them. I headed home about 9pm after watching the game and chatting with a few locals. When I went outside I discovered how dark it was. I had just jumped on my bike and started ridding, but 10 seconds after getting on the road, I realized I could barely see the white lines as there was so little light. I went back to the parking lot and cut the twisty type that was holding the dynamo from touching the tire. I road around the parking lot for a few minutes to see if the lights would come on, but the front light flickered for a minute and went out but the back light looked like it was fine, just a little dim. I decided to just go for it, as it was only 10-15 minutes down the road. As I climbed the hill from the pub the road seemed to disappear from beneath and the sky above became much more pronounced. I had not realized, but there was not a cloud in the sky to be found and being as I was in the middle of nowhere, there were no city lights to dim the stars effect. Thus, the stars were incredibly bright. It felt like sitting in the planetarium at the Natural Science Museum where the screen illuminates the stars on the screen for effect. So there I was with one of the most beautiful skies I have seen, riding my bike as quickly and safely as possible with no lights down the dark roads of the west coast of New Zealand. After a few minutes the first 18-wheeler came down the road and helped shine a light on the road. I quickly moved to the side and let him pass, as not to risk falling and running into the road. There were probably 5-6 cars on the ride home, and each of them were surely surprised to see me! It was an awesome ride that really got my heart racing. Not sure that I would do it again, but I lived to tell the story.
The next day I set out to do a short ride, as I wanted to get some time to read and chill. I went onto Mokau where I had that fritter and checked out the local museum that told the story of the natives fighting the Brits no too many years ago. I was told by the American running the campground that I could came on the river just outside of Mokau (10 miles), but it turns out that those were the days of yore and not of the current much more strict camping rules. So I continued down the road hoping to stumble across another campsite.
The next feature of the day was not a place to put my tent, but instead what the locals warn all bikers about (expect I missed this message), which is Mt. Messenger! It starts as a slow climb, but after each turn lends itself to another kilometer long climb, I started to think that this baby was going to be big. I have not dismounted from my bike on any hills, except when my bike broke outside of Hamilton. So I set my head down, looking at the next few feet in front of me, focusing on pedaling the next 10 meters, not the next mile. When the hill was less steep I kept my bike in high gear as to let myself rest with the easier cycles, and when it got steep again I put that pedal down and mashed it up the mountain. After watching signs indicating the end of the passing lane…8km, 5km, 3km…I figured I was getting near the top. After what I would guess was a 3-4mile climb, I hit the top of the dang thing and was met by a tourist taking photos of the awesome view and me. There was also an 18 wheeler making adjustments to his truck before heading down. He set off down the road just before I made it to the top, so I ended up chasing him down the other side! He might have beat me up the hill, but I was definitely winning the race down. Unfortunately, it’s probably not too safe to pass an 18 wheeler on a bike, but it would have been funny to see his face! The road drops you out into a valley filled with farms and animals. I pulled off, dropped my bike, and consumed all the peanut butter and jelly I could!
The next few miles were beautiful, but there were not any campsites. I knew that once I made it back to the coast there would be some, but I was not sure how far they were. I was not mentally set on riding a long way that day, so I ended up pulling off the road just before Mimi, when I saw a couple enjoying tea on their porch. I headed up to inquire if they knew how far it was to the next campground, and they said it wasn’t but a few kilometers, but that I could stay in their spare bedroom if I liked. Man, I love being on a bike!
Berry and Joy were my hosts for the eventful night in Mimi. Berry and Steve gutted a hog, Joy told stories of her travels to Bali, and Steve showed my picks of his upcoming hunting trip to South Africa where you can shot everything from zebras to giraffes. He was not interested in killing this big boys as it costs a small fortune to put a bullet in them, but he was very keen on getting out there and seeing how the animals interacted. It was a great night with a warm shower, hot meal of wild hog sausage, and friendly kiwis.
[gallery]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks Morgan. I will do my best.
I love reading about your adventures! Keep on having a great time!

item.title: Masterton Marathon
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[gallery]
Well, it’s the morning after the race and it feels like the race was years ago. I think that might be due to the fact that it was so emotional at the time. Getting back into the mentality of those last for miles is something I hope to experience again in my lifetime.
The Red River Shootout was on at 5am in New Zealand the morning of the race, so in between preparing breakfast and getting dressed, I was cheering on the horns who’s defense looked good at the time! I had to leave after the first quarter, so as far as I knew we were in good shape.
We made it to Makoura College around 6:15am; giving me enough time to register and try to warm up. It could not have been much warmer than 40 degrees out as there was frost on the fields. During registration, I met a middle aged Kiwi who said this was his 50th marathon, and he was returning to Masterton for it, as there is where the journey began for him!
We headed to the start line, with about 100 people and you could see lots of cold faces, but definitely a lot a determination in their eyes. With a 2 minutes left before the gun, I removed my jacket and shirt, leaving me with trail runners, shorts, an iPod, finger tight gloves, and a Texas flag bandana. I was the only one out of these experienced locals that was bare-chested! Kerry said I got a lot of strange looks from the folks around me, and I definitely was on the receiving end of a few smart remarks on the road.
The gun fired and we set out on the 26.3mi/42km course through the farmlands of Masterton. I usually start me runs with a few podcasts, as it keeps my mind busy hearing the stories. However, once I got out to the open road I was surrounded by thick fogs as the frost was burning off the rugby pitches and lake just out side of town. It was a gorgeous morning and the birds were chirping, so I turned off the pod for a bit and soaked it in. After a bit of that, I resorted to my favorites, Explosions in the Sky. They helped propel me through the first half of the race and a 15 minutes ahead of my 4-hour pace!
I continued to feel fresh for the beginning of the second lap, but it wasn’t long before I started to feel the pain of the road. From kilometer 25 to 35, I was struggling to keep my pace up, but was able to at least stay below 9-minute miles. The whole time I was thinking that I am going to hit a wall as I was so far ahead of my goal, but it wasn’t happening. At the 35km marker I was met by my two Kiwi hosts, Kerry and Loreen, as well as my UK friends from a few weeks prior, Sophie, Simon and Nia who drove all the way from New Plymouth! I had been holding back a bit before this point as I thought that I was going to hit a wall if I came out too hard, but I was feeling good enough to make a push. Seeing the gang there, after 20 miles on the road, was a feeling that I cannot describe. Having friends that I have only met in the last few weeks come out to support me in the wee hours of the morning, is a gesture that I will be forever grateful for. Knowing I had their support, realizing that I was close to my original goal, and having fuel left in the tank led me to start to emotionally loose it. I broke out in a slow weep that I could hardly control, but felt so pure. I picked up the pace to what felt like a 7 minute pace and was able to hold that for 3-4 miles weeping tears of happiness along the way. What a strange feeling and refreshing feeling! After this push, I really started to feel exhausted and could not keep the pace. This is when Kerry starting stopping every kilometer along to route to pump me up. He knew I was close to that goal of 3:30. These last few miles were very tough and would have been a lot worse if I didn’t have Kerry and Loreen there pushing me on. What joy there was seeing them around each turn.
As I made it back into town it looked like I was not going to make the 3:30 mark, but that I wasn’t going to be too far off. I tried to move my legs quicker, but they were not cooperating. I instead set into the pace that they would give me and cruised into the finish line. I was met with my new friends and glasses of water and Gatorade. I greeted all of them with a big sweaty hug, which they later said was a bit gross, but was all I could give them, as I couldn’t get a word out. After trying to standup and talk, I finally gave up and lay on the ground weeping softly with tears of happiness slowly making their way out. I was completely exhausted, relieved, proud, grateful, and happy. I had made it after 9 weeks of training in 4 countries on islands, in the mountains, and on the beach.
It took me a good 20 minutes to catch my breath and begin to start to talk again. We discussed the run and we decided that this is something that everyone should go through in some way at least once. Even if you cannot participate, showing up at the finish line to see the raw emotion, is something to behold.
There were probably 100 people entered in the marathon, and maybe 40 in my bracket. I came out with a time of 3 hours, 33 minutes, and 40 seconds. Good enough for 19th overall and 11th in my bracket. A few weeks prior, I ran 21 miles in 3 hours and 45 minutes, so I thought just making it in less than 4 hours was going to be a feat. When I first started training, I was hoping to average 8-minute miles, which would give me a time of about 3 hours and 30 minutes. While I didn’t quite hit that initial goal, I was still ecstatic to get so close to it and frankly, to have crushed the 4-hour mark that I was targeting that morning.
Thanks to all of my new friends for coming out! Thanks to Sophie for showing up and being such a good caregiver at the end of the road. She removed my shoes (what relief that brought), got me food, and provided many other things I am sure! Thanks to Simon for showing up and telling me to pickup the pace on the road when I was starting to lag! Also, for the kind words after the race. To Nia, for buying me a delicious chicken and ham sandwhich after the run and for bringing me an incredibly refreshing Montieths Radler and for your dedication in making sure you made it out to support me! Thanks to Kerry and Loreen for driving me to the race at 5:45 in the morning, providing a massive dinner of lamb the night before, providing words of encouragement all along the road, and for the many other things that are too many to name! Your Kiwi hospitality is some of the best I have come across.
Results: http://techs.net.nz/trusthouse.co.nz/sport/athletics/marathon_results.htm
Pics: http://www.photosales.co.nz/details.php?gid=730&pid=138102

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Dude, love the Texas Flag bandana. And keep up the writing, I've really enjoyed it.
Cheers Brett!

item.title: Biking across the Rimutakas and World Cup Rugby in Wellington
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[gallery]
It was an exciting ride into Wellington. While resting in Greytown, I stopped at the Library and hoped on the free Wi-Fi to check emails and make sure I was on track with my route. Before I could even get my email open, a man stopped and inquired about my bike. Next thing I knew, I was staying the night at his place and hearing about his recent biking trip from Vancouver to Denver! John and Ann are in there 70’s, but that did not deter them from making the mountainous trip over 2 months riding a state of the art tandem bike. They have been biking all their life, reaching places as remote as Pakistan. They really enjoy being out in the saddle, and it was inspirational to hear them talk about it as if it were no big deal for a 70 year old to do.
I spent the day at their house working on the computer and going through the stack of books they both kept bringing me! They have lots of different passions and had books on all of them that they wanted to share. Things such as a sales brochure for their super high tech bike hub that only has one shifter and can be shifted when stopped, child psychology books about bringing kids up in nature, comedy by David Berry, that Indian paintbrush child’s book, etc. They also introduced me to “Letters from America”, which is a BBC program by Alistair Cooke, who provides really good insight into current events and has a killer British accent. John also has a dear friend who was an American Marine back in WWII. He had Byron come and speak to his class about the war, which he record, and we listened to. It was really powerful stuff. One bit that stood out to me was that while he was in the trenches, he knew that the soldiers on the other side where not to blame for the war and likely didn’t want to be there either, but it was mandated that they were the enemy and that they must be destroyed, so he did. During the talk, Byron spoke about all the islands he had been stationed on, and about many of the battle they had, and what equipment they were using, and what food they ate...and it reminded me that there is so much to know and experience and I have seen so little of it and understand only a small fraction of the information out there. Striving to know it all and understand it all will never be possible, so I suppose it is best to follow things that interest you and share that knowledge and those experiences whenever possible.
The next day I set out to cross the Rimutakas. I had been warned about them by everyone from Woodville to Featherson. It is a narrow two-lane road that winds up 8 miles around dramatic Tararua Mountain views and is the only way into Wellington from this side of the island. People told me that sometimes bikers do it, but there isn’t much of a shoulder and there are lots of blind turns. It was not until I met John, the biker in Greytown, that I got a realistic report on biking over them. He said that lots of people do it, there is a shoulder for most of it, cars go slowly up, and that Kiwi drivers are considerate to bikers for the most part. His account of the pass turned out to be the most accurate of the lot. While there were blind turns and very narrow shoulders at times, I never really felt at risk. When coming around tight turns, drivers stayed behind me and were patient before passing on the next straight away. I guess the lesson is pretty simple, seek advice from people who have experience in what you are trying to do. If I had listened to the naysayers and taken the train, I would have missed the dramatic views, challenging ride, and sense of accomplishment of making the climb in one go! I strapped my camera to the front of my bike on the way down to take a video, so I will try to post some of that at some point.
About 10 miles outside of Wellington I got a slow leak in my front tire, so I could ride, but had to fill up my tube every few minutes. I got it repaired in town, but it popped 2 more times that weekend! Flats really do seem to come in streaks. I went a month without a flat and then got 3 in one weekend. It’s sorted at the moment, so hopefully it will hold up in the mountains of the South Island.
I stayed with a Canadian from Nova Scotia in Wellington and had a great time experiencing the city with him. He is a big fan of all types of music (lots of Canadian bands, indie rock, hip hop, and jazz), so we had a few late nights of playing tunes for each other. My iTunes collection continues to grow!
It was the semi-finals of the Rugby World Cup, so we had France v Wales on Saturday and New Zealand v Australia on Sunday. We caught most of the Wales game at an old friends house, followed by a big night out that included the Alice and Wonderland bar where we were let in only after proving that we were good guys due to our patience, dancing with a Bahamian (?), and watching Minuit live. Minuit is a girl and 2 DJ’s from Nelson, NZ who played with a lot of passion and was well known by the crowd of a few hundred. Her songs are a little repetitive at times, but they are great for dancing too and definitely catchy.
Kiwi’s are incredibly cautious about counting their chickens before they hatch with regards to the All Blacks because they have had their hopes dashed several times in recent history. The team is always at the top of the charts and is known as the greatest team in rugby, but they have choked at the last few World Cups. We went to watch the NZ game Sunday night at Molly’s pub, which appeared to be mostly locals in the joint, as there were not a bunch of shaggy ragamuffins like myself. The Kiwi’s we were closest to showed nervousness in their expressions as the game began. Australia beat the All Blacks in the last game of the Tri-Nations, so supports were very wary about facing them again so soon. Within the first 5 minutes it was clear that the AB’s came to play and brought their A-game. They controlled the pace of the game, but were not scoring many try’s. This was not comforting to the locals and it was not until the final few minutes that they finally loosened up a bit and started to even smile! One lady said to me that Americans are too emotional and talk about their feeling more than they should! This was hilarious coming from a female and from one that clearly needed to talk about her emotions because the AB’s were definitely stressing her out. I told her that guys in America, as far as I know, are not known for sharing their emotions and they she would make many American men happy if this was her mentality. I think was she was referring to was that we get really fired up for sports. We definitely do and it’s really a risk/reward thing. If you follow your team closely, investing time and emotion into their success, then it is going to hurt and change your mood if they loose, but if they win, then the joy that brings can make years of heartache feel like it was worth it. I think those AB fans need to show more emotion and get fired up for their boys, as they are about to win the cup after walking all over France next week! If you are interested in watching, the game will be on at 3am in the States next Sunday.
On Sunday I met a past host’s daughter in town and had a great conversation about anthropology, travel, and following your dreams. I have really enjoyed meeting people from different backgrounds and walks of life. Hearing their story always provides another perspective to look at the world through.
After tea with Evi, I wondered around the Cuba St markets in search of a hipster type coffee shop to hopefully meet some more people. I wrote for a bit, sitting at a table and not really in a position to bump into someone, so I moved my things and plate of kumera fries (so dank) up to the counter with seats pointed out of the street. Within minutes a young girl sat next to me enjoying her coffee and reading a bit. I just asked how she was doing and 30 minutes later we exchanged emails after a great conversation on where we both were at the moment and where we are going. She is hoping to be a graphic designer, so I am hoping I can help her along that path in the future!
These conversations with recommended people and random strangers really got me pumped to be in a city. This is how I want to see cities. Not in their museums or on the water front, but in the coffee shops and pubs where the locals past the days sipping teas and embracing what the city offers them. Definitely stocked to get into another major city, but that is going to be Christchurch, which will be a very interesting place to meet locals, as from what I hear, are still traumatized from the quakes and continued tremors.
I am on a massive ferry that runs from Wellington to Picton. The windows are a little fogged up and its drizzling out, but the sounds and islands out the window are really something.
New goals:
Bike over Lewis Pass in the South Island of New Zealand on the way to Christchurch.
Do the Chiang Mai (northern Thailand) marathon on Christmas Day in under 3 hours and 17 minutes, which is a 7 minute and 30 second mile average.
Only eat local foods. Thinking back to some of my previous posts, my discussions with Marshall ended with the idea that getting your goods and food locally is one of the best things that can be done for the environment. I want to do my best over the next few months to buy local peanut butter, beer, granola bars, nuts, etc.
Write everyday. It doesn’t have to be an entire blog or about anything. I just want to get in the habit of putting pen to paper more often and see what comes of it.
Current books:
Finished Siddhartha Working on Cosmos
It is interesting reading these books in succession. Siddhartha talks a lot about oneness and how everything in the world is connected...rivers, trees, people, the wind, etc. It speaks about Sid’s need to find his purpose in life not from reading and understanding doctrine, but instead from going out and experiencing things for yourself and seeing the beauty in everyday things. Cosmos, Carl Sagan’s scientific account of the world, stars, and space, starts off talking about how scientifically we are very closely connected to all living things in our genetic makeup. That the fundamental building blocks and set of instructions for flowers are really not that much different from our own. Fascinating to see a philosopher and scientist having such similar thoughts of the world. Unity. Connectedness. Oneness.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi andrew, enjoyed reading your wonderings and travel experiences. If you are open to other people, people open up to you. There are still plenty of nice and friendly people out there and the way you travel will give you the opportunity to get in touch with them. The nay sayers will never see the world the way you do. As long as you use common sense, I think -and have experienced myself- that traveling and meeting new people broadens one's horizon in a great way. Keep on enjoying your self! Yvonne
Well said Yvonne! An open mind and positive outlook appear to lead to good times and a chance to get to know people for who they are. Thanks for the support.

item.title: Birthday Beer Run
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: On October 26th at 10am I had in my possession 1 apple and 1 small bag of nuts. The posted sign near the hut says 3 hours to the parking lot. From the lot, its 3km to the nearest town (Springs Junction) and 45km to the nearest town (Reefton) with adult beverages. By 8pm that night, I would have snacks on snacks and plenty of drinks to ensure everyone could have a good time. I got going pretty slowly that morning, as I did not have much of a plan. I started reading Walden and then visited a bit the fisherman. At the carpark, I had more rice and tuna stashed with my bike, but no celebratory drinks. Around noon I got a bit restless from sitting and writing. I decided to run the trail and then try to hitchhike into town. The weather had been off and on that morning, but at decision-making time, it was warm and the rain was holding off. I packed my bag very lightly, just taking a jacket, water and money. I started down the trail around 12:15 and became quickly winded after about 3km. The hills, awkward pack, and now heavy rain had slowed me down to a fast walk. It was an awesome feeling running through the bush with the rain pouring down, but tough to keep up the pace. I definitely have a lot of respect for trail runners. At 1:30pm, I made it to the carpark, and was greeted by a couple from Christchurch. She was going on the first tramp of her life, and he was doing his best to drive her nuts. They made me a cup of coffee, as they said it looked like I could use one in my soaked state. While enjoying the cup, they offered to drive me into Springs Junction, as it might be easier to get a ride to Reefton. I took them up on the offer, and Brian gave me a lift. From SJ, I started walking toward Reefton, figuring that if I showed an effort, people would be more likely to pick me up. After 20 minutes, I started to think that I might want to stay near town, if I need to bail on the plan. I posted up near a section of gravel where it would be easy for a car to pull off. By this time, the rain had let up, so the sun was drying my gear and lifting my spirits. To pass the time, I through on Gramatik and had a mini dance party on the side of the road. I was only seeing a car every ten minutes and none of them where giving me much of a second thought. I decided to take the shoulder funky fest back to town, where I might be able to catch people getting into their cars. 10 minutes into the walk back, a SUV pulled over and a lovely pre-school teacher from Reefton greeted me with a smile. She was returning from visiting her son in Christchurch and had no qualms with sharing the ride with a stranger. She was surprised to hear that I had waiting an hour and a half to get a lift! I received a good update on the state of things in the city; that the people are not in shock anymore, many people have left the city, her mom was in a casino and was nearly hit by a chandelier during the February quake and was strangely unfazed by this (the mom), that insurance companies are waiting for all the aftershocks to pass (which could take years) before starting to pay for rebuilding, there are sections of the town that will not be rebuilt and they are giving the residents 16 months to get out. She dropped me on the main drag of Reefton, pointing out the pub, backpackers, library, and supermarket. I went straight for the library to check my email, but didn’t have the message I was hoping for. After killing 30 minutes there, I went to the grocery store and bought cookies, 2 bags of chips, more rice and tuna, a steak and cheese meat pie!, and a box of New Zealand’s finest budget wine. Half of the mission was complete. With the time reading 4pm, I needed to start making my way back as I hoped to make it back before nightfall. I popped open the cookies and chips and had a snackfest on the edge of town leading out to Springs Junction. On the ride in, I was told that there was a gold mine just out of town that was booming with the gold prices being so high. I am not sure if they were gold miners, but I saw tons of shuttles running people in and out of the town, none of which were able to pride a ride. However, after another hour, a miner took pity on me and said he could at least get me to the next small town 3km down the road, oddly enough. He dropped me in front of a mining museum after a brief 5-minute ride. I opened up the Explosions jam fest in the lawn of the museum, and within 15 minutes, was on my way back to the carpark with a farmer from SJ. He is a master tracker in the bush, pointing to keen observation and remembering counts of ridges and streams, as keys to his success. He also raises dogs to hunt male boars and says that many people seek out his pups as they don’t bite the pigs much and know which pigs are male or female. He also told me about the 1080 poison that the DOC puts out to create kill zones between valleys in the bush to prevent the spread of disease and wipe out the possums in the area. While the poison does kill everything with a mouth, it apparently has worked in some areas, as native birds have thrived in the post-apocalyptic areas. He was kind enough to take me all the way to the trailhead and since it was my birthday, left me with a present. 20 minutes later, I am hiking back to the Manson-Nichol’s Hut on Lake Daniels. I have been hiking a lot in the last two weeks and I can tell that my legs are getting into good climbing shape. I had a banging pace going up the rolling path, but in my heightened state of being from the adventures of the day, was really enjoying the views of the river, forest, and valleys. Things I had been wrestling with in my mind over the past few days all started to make sense, the world around me was sweeter, my hunger was gone, and I didn’t feel any kind of tired. The hike took an hour and a half, putting me back at the cozy, stove warmed hut by 8pm. The two younger fisherman of the group greeted me upon my return, laughing that they were starting to get worried about the American. I went inside the hut and laughed it up with the old guys about how must trouble I had gone though to get supplies. I was successful at sharing my wine with them, but none of them took any of the cookies or chips, so I ended eating all of them. It was a great way to end my 26th birthday, sharing wine and stories with 6 fisherman from the South Island of New Zealand. Cheers folks.

item.title: I was one of the lucky ones
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
To have pen and paper to capture my thoughts To have the gift of introspection To witness the Waioeka Gorge in the rain To speak the language of the locals To be in a foreign place and not be in fear To converse with different generations of an indigenous people To be able to make friends at home and in new corners of the world To have saved money to take the journey of my dreams To have an interest in a line of work that compensates with a livable wage To have chosen a major that companies wanted to hire To have parents that supported me emotionally and financially To have loving parents and siblings To be healthy and intelligent at the result of millions of years of evolution To be given the gift of life, even with the stipulation of death To begin to grasp the vastness of eternity
I am grateful and will try my best to do the right by these gifts As I have no excuse to do otherwise
[gallery]
