item.title: Why don’t you just go home and blog about it?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: [gallery] I am currently on a bus to Dunedin after spending 2 months bike touring New Zealand. As adventures often go, it ended up being something much different than what I expected. I think the biggest surprise to me was that I enjoy meeting people on the road more than the biking itself. When I took my first stab at planning this tour, I focused on covering huge distances with very few rest days. At that point, the goal was to cover as much ground as my legs would take me and to catch as many USA Eagles Rugby World Cup games as possible. After two days on the road, I quickly realized that the winter weather, hills, and weight of my bags were going to make for a tour filled with 10-12 hour days in the saddle with little time to stop and smell ‘em roses. I called an audible, and with the help of 4 inspiring days with a couch surfer in Hamilton, decided to scale back the mileage and focus more on seeing towns, beaches, and meeting the people of New Zealand. After 51 days of travel, 900 miles, and about 20 days on the bike, I arrived in Christchurch. As is one lesson from The Alchemist, it is often the journey itself, more than the completing a goal, that’s where joy comes from. For me, it was a little anti-climatic arriving in Christchurch. There were no banners, no people in the street cheering, no medals, no ice cream, and no handshakes. There was a brief feeling a accomplishment, but this was quickly taken over by my wondering mind working out what to do next. That is pretty ridiculous, but fine by me, as the memories from the journey are really what I am going to take away from the trip, no just the last few moments. The following list is comprised of thoughts that came to mind while reflecting over a cup of tea and cone of hokey pokey on the last day. My feeling on sharing and reading life lessons is that the majority of the time they are hard to relate to and really aren’t understood or every realized until you experience it yourself. Although, they sometimes they can give me a goal or purpose and sometimes very luckily, articulate my thoughts in a way that I was unable to do. With that being said, take ‘em or leave ‘em. There is nothing special about what I did or what I am doing. Anyone can do it, if they really wanted to. Lots of people live out their dreams of travel in many different ways. The trick is just taking the first step. The rest tends to work itself out. Age, family, and money are not the issue. It is more about how much your desire to do it. Patience and an open mind will be keys to the success of this. Wanting things to happen the way you want or expect will no doubt lead to disappointment. Here are a few examples… Ann and John are a couple from Greytown that bike toured from Vancourver to Denver on a tandem bike in what I think was two months. What’s more impressive than biking over the Rocky Mountains on a 2-seater? Doing it when you are in your 70’s. Great work guys. Sue and Bruce from Nelson had 2 kids, but were not done travelling. When their kids were around ages 4 and 7, they sold all of their possessions, bought a canal boat, and toured England via small channels for 8 months. They started off home-schooling, but after a few days decided it sucked and that life on the road would teach them more than they could learn in 8 months of school. The trick for them on not making it too stressful was not trying to do too much with the kids. Sue said that the worst days of the trip were when they went to museums and other tourist attractions and try to cram in everything there was to see. They had much better days just living simply and modestly on the boat. As far as money goes, it can be expensive to get places, but once you are there you can survive on very small budgets. Toby, from England, spent $900 in 7 weeks of travel in Southeast Asia. It can be argued about whether this is sustainable for the country and that this is a very poor part of the world, but we can look at other examples. I spent $4000 in the first 3 months of travel, which was enough to surf, buy a bike, go to the RWC opening match, and go out for beers here and there. I did spend about $1500 on flights during this portion, but since I might be staying in New Zealand a bit longer, that money spent on flights is going to last a lot longer. Don’t be afraid to ask for help or be in need of it, but be ready to offer something. Could just be lending an ear or it could be providing medical advice. And an example: I have countless examples of this on my trip, but I think my favorite was near Wanganui. I stopped at an Art Gallery to rest from a dull day of riding. I said I was looking for a place to stay in Wanganui and that I needed to check my email to see if any couch surfers had responded. She offered up her laptop to let me check. I checked and no one had accepted, so I moved on to help get her computer running faster, as she was complaining about the performance. While troubleshooting the machine, she got a call from a friend in town, and moments later I had a bed to stay in for the weekend. Going without things makes you appreciate them or realize that they are not needed. And an example: While riding the bike, I tried to keep my bag weight under control, so that meant small meals using foods that kept well in the elements. I learned to really enjoy my rice, tuna, and turmeric, but when I got to a town and was able to get a cookie or basket of fries, it always felt like these were the best things I had ever tasted. Any ideology/custom/believe can be argued successfully, so it’s up to you to find the ones that suit you best. There are no right and wrong beliefs, just different approaches and perceptions of the world and how to deal with it. There are faults and good that come from each of them. Bike touring is hard and I have lots of respect for the people that bike across the world. I am surprised to see how popular that is and how many times it has been done. Check out this Israeli that biked across the world: www.dreamwithopeneyes.com Mingle with the locals. Do an activity that lends itself to exposing you to them. Don’t make plans, and don’t bring a map. This will put you in a vulnerable situation, forcing you to reach out, and giving people the opportunity to help you. Getting lost is an opportunity, not a devastating event. Everyone has a story and/or something to offer/good in them if you are patient enough to allow it to emerge. I met a guy while watching the Rugby World Cup final who was a very well educated and well-spoken Kiwi. We shared an all you can eat meal together and then had a few beers while watching the game. We spoke about where we were going in life, opera, music across generations, life in NZ, etc. We both went our separate ways after the match, but on a gut feeling, I decided to inquire if he wanted to checkout Explosions in the Sky and have a few more brews. We met at his spot, as I was in a 6-person bunk. I know what you are probably thinking, “Cobb, you are going to some strangers motel at midnight to have a beer? Do you want to get killed? Are you looking for action?” Oddly enough, these thoughts and concerns did not cross my mind. He was an interesting dude and I wanted to share some music with him. We ended up chatting until 5 in the morning and was honored enough to hear his life story. He is a gay man, but has not come out to many people. Since he was falsely accused of a crime he has suffered a lot of stress these past two years. It has made him lose trust in others and paranoid at times. You could see the pain this caused from his body language. I was shocked that he would open up this information to me, but also felt a connection and even happiness that I was lending an ear and giving him a chance to open up and reflect on the events of the past few years. He is a good man and I hope he is able to find peace again. Be flexible while traveling This morning created an interesting story for this tag. I booked with Naked Bus to Dunedin and read on their site that you have to give warning that you are bring a bike and that it need to have the pedals and chains removed. Seeing as how I didn’t have the tools to do that and that I needed to ride to bike to catch the bus, I made the assumption that it wouldn’t be a busy bus on Sunday morning and that they would let me on with it. When I rode up on my fat Shogun pannier bags in tow, he took one look at me and shaking his head informed me that since the bus would be full, there would be no room for the bike. I had 7 minutes to get rid of the bike or loose my ticket. I called Simon, a fellow biker, but he didn’t answer. I called Richard and told him about it and he said he would be happy to pickup the bike, but of course, he couldn’t make it there in under 7 minutes. I ended up locking the bike to a streetlight and “hiding” the key in the lovely garden of a house at 62 Bealey St. I got on the bus and an hour later got a text from Richard saying he had acquired the bike. Haha, oh man, can’t believe that worked. Now I need to find a bike in Dunedin!It cannot be understated on how relatively easy it was to bike tour in New Zealand because it is an English speaking country. Also, most small towns do not have problems with theft/violence, so that took off a lot of stress. I would definitely recommend touring here.Looking out the window at the flat farmlands south of Christchurch, I am very happy that I did not bike this. It’s pretty dull scenery and could probably get extremely windy due to the lack of trees.   I just sold my first WordPress project, and independent consulting project for that matter, and am going to spend the next month living in Dunedin working on that. I hear there are good coffee shops and a young vibe, which sounds enjoyable. Also, most students are leaving town for summer, leaving empty flats, hopefully at a low price. Books Read Into Thin Air at 1600meters at the Angelus Hut – this book showed me how resilient the human body can be. While many people perished, it was incredible that so many survived through the night at the highest hikable altitudes in the world. It also reinforced that I have no interest in climbing Everest. Of Mice and Men – interesting read, but honestly not sure what to take from it. I need to take 5 minutes on the web to find out the context of it. Steve Jobs – Just getting started with this one and am really enjoying it. The title comes from a few guys poking fun at travelers always worrying about keeping their blogs up to date.  I guess I am guilty.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks for sharing your experiences. I love the openness and faith in humanity you seem to be cultivating. Not that it wasn't there before, but I feel the "every day" life in American causes us to judge, fear, and separate ourselves from humanity so much. I believe wholeheartedly in the over-riding goodness of humanity and am happy to be able to follow along with your journey in discovering this. <3
Awesome Andrew sounds like you are having a great time :)
Awesome writeup, Cobb. Would love to chat with you more about your travels when you return from your quest.
Thanks dude. Maybe you should just meet me on the road!
Thanks Lou. Indeed, things are going well.

This means a lot coming from you Kim. You have been an inspiration to me in that you are able to bring out the best in people, even in the sometimes uppity/wealth focused clubs and bars of the dirty D. Love, peace, and beats!
Really enjoyed reading about your adventure. Keep it up, sounds like quite an adventure.
Thanks Shawna! I always enjoy your latest photography posts! Keep it up.

Still jealous, if you can give me some insights on how I can get Wendy to agree to let me do something like this I would appreciate it. I'm happy to hear about your experiences and continue to wish for you to have a safe and fulfilling journey.
Simple bro, tell her it's a great cultural experience for the children.
It's doable! http://www.sixintheworld.com/an-overivew-of-the-trip/
Nice find Kim! It's definitely doable. You just have to want it.

item.title: A month in Dunedin
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: [gallery]   During one of the final weeks of my cycle from Auckland to Christchurch, I met a world traveler from the Netherlands, who currently lives in Melbourne, Australia. We had some great talks about her motorcycle journeys in remote parts of the world and, since she was a Nike marketing director in her past, how I could get funding from a big shoe company to hike my way around the world in runners. We also touched on the fact that they were redoing their website in WordPress. I said I could probably find someone back home to do it, but when I couldn’t, I decided to take it myself. The result of which was me moving to Dunedin for 4 weeks to get to know Dunedin, it’s people, and get some solid coding sessions in. I took the bus to Dunedin a few days after accepting the job, and within 5 hours of arriving, found a great short term flat in Roslyn, which is a 20 minute hike up from the Octagon in city centre. Flatmates Henry – Yerba Mate, jack of all trades Beale – Bealean Religion, MBA, poet, IT industry in Gisborne The flat posting said they were looking for mature young adults and that the current flatmates were engineers, masters’ students, and MBA’s. It sounded like a good environment to get work done and could lend itself to meeting some interesting cats. They were better than expected. Henry is a jack-of-all-trades, whose job title changes as fast as the weather in New Zealand. In the short time I lives there, he did a painting job, bartended, helped his brother start a restaurant, gave tours of the city, consulted for the redesign of a nice restaurant in town, and taught Spanish to eager pupils. There were probably even more jobs that that, but it’s all I can recall at the moment. He was also a wiz in the kitchen, making 2am pies, fresh bread, and of course, kiwi sausages. He taught how easy it was to make bread. While it is a bit time consuming and messy, it is really enjoyable to make a 50 cent loaf that tastes fresher than the $5 loaf at the store. It worked well with my coding, as I could write for a bit, kneed some dough, then get back to writing. He also introduced me to Yerba Mate, which is a South American delicacy that is shared throughout the day among friends. It’s a pumped up tea with lots of antioxidants, more caffeine than normal (but less than coffee) and a unique taste that I found quite pleasant. Checkout someplace like Wholefoods to grab a bag. If you want to get traditional about it, you can buy a gorde and super special mate straw, which will let you make even stronger cups of mate. Beale was no less impressive than Henry. He has traveled and lived in Australia for extended amounts of time, writes poetry and short stories, is working on his MBA, plays guitar like a champ, started his own religion, and enjoys philosophizing about cultures and women. It is very interesting that he is a artsy guy who is now getting corporatified via an Otago MBA. I love that he sent poems to the MBA mailing list and recited them at events. It must have been great for the program to have a creative mind in the mix. Beale also has an interesting taste in movies. We watched a few together: - Three Colors – White: Euro film about love lost and revenge. - As it is in Heaven: Heart warming movie about a composer in Sweden, which gives a interesting insight into their chilly lives - Salo: Oh man, be careful with this one. We only watched the first 30 minutes, but even that made it one of the most disturbing films I have seen. The film tries to capture what life was like in Italy during the Second World War. The display of power by the elders was disgusting. Not sure how much of it was accurate, but seeing as how the filmmaker was murdered, it probably had a little more than they had hoped would be shown. Watch it tonight Toy. - Man with a Movie Camera: Very unique cinematography is in one. It was taped in one shot in one building in Russia. Definitely worth a watch if you are a patient person. - Goodby Pork Pie: A classic in New Zealand, documenting what life was like here in the 80s. Beale says it captures the time well, saying that no one knew where they were going, so they just drifted around taking whatever adventures came their way. Great kiwi slang in this bad boy. - Boy: A film about Maori life out in the Gisborne area. Someone said that too many Maori films are really depressing, but that this one tells the story of hardship while making it a laugh as well. New skillz I tried or got into a few new things while in the weather chaos zone that is Dunedin. As I mentioned, I got into bread making. I also jumped on an opportunity to try bikram yoga, as it was only $20 for a week. I went the first day and really enjoyed it because it was to hot, and New Zealand is so cold. The positions were tough, and definitely toughed in 105-degree heat. I managed to make it through without passing out, but did have to stop and lay down a few times to let my body catch up. The second day was much worse. I might have overdone it early, or more likely, didn’t drink enough water ahead of time. I made it through 3/4s of the session, but then spent most of the last 20 minutes just lying on my back trying not to pass out. It’s a really intense hour an a half, that felt good to make it through, but I am not sure that its for me. It was fun, but takes a lot of time, as it took me at least an hour or two to recover after each session. I am sure that if I stuck with it, that would get better, but from what I hear it can be expensive and I would rather be outside to get my exercise. Also, I don’t think I can handle the feisty instructors barking at me every morning to do more, be more, give it more! I also picked myself up a guitar. I figure that I am going to have a decent amount of free time on this trip with my mom and when I make it to New Plymouth. Better late then never to give it a run. Life in Dunedin I found Dunedin to be a great town. Some people give it crap because the weather can be terribly unpredictable, there are too many students, and its not Wellington. However, it does have some solid little cafes and bars and some very interesting people. My first weekend in the city, I got invited to work at the Circulation Festival. It is a 4-day event that brings together street performs, yoga instructors, and jugglers of all kinds to share their talents in workshop fashion. Each day there are dozens of workshops put on by patrons of the festival. The workshops were things like how to exercise on a stripper pole, how to take yoga to the next level by “flying”, juggling instruction of all kinds, tree climbing when there are not many branches, and much more. I only ended up being out there for 24 hours, but that was enough time to get flown by a 250 pound Maori (flying yoga is when one person lays on their back and lifts you into the air with their legs and stretch you from that position), do that tree climbing thing, and be a bouncer for the festivals Saturday night massive field party. I have never seen so many corky people in one place, but I have to say that it worked and they seemed to really get along well. Anything went as far as clothing and activites, making the people watching quite enjoyable. I hit the farmers market each Saturday morning and convinced the roommates to get in on splitting massive amounts of veggies each week. For 8-10 bucks a week, we had all the eggs, broccoli, boc choi, onions, green onions, lemons, and cauliflower you could eat. I also got some local honey and tea, that were both very dank. My third weekend there, I was invited to a beach birthday party in a cave a few miles out of the city. That ended up being an amazing 18 hours, filled with beach disc, running, rock climbing, mate, violin and guitars by the fire, running into ravers who were still going from the day before, and meeting some very cool and well traveled people. There were a lot of PHD students there, whom appears to have mixed feeling about getting their doctorate. Some were stoked to be doing sweet research projects that involved catching penguins, while others didn’t know why they were spending so much time and money to feed cells in petri dishes. One girl was getting her masters at Oxford in England, working at a sustainability clinic in Dunedin, and running two NGO’s in Peru that she started while backpacking there. Boom! That is probably the most impressive resume I have met on the road. Mad props to her. I also attended the Dunedin Polytechnic end of year art show. One of the highlights was a wall of rings with hand-written notes attached to them. It was an interactive piece that instructed its visitors to write the worst breakup lines they have ever heard. People really got into it and there were some very creative entries that would have made a grown man cry. My most frequent hangout was a coffee shop/bar that was dubbed the smallest bar in the world, called Mou. They had my favorite beer of the time, Emersons Pilsner, and since the bar was so tiny, it was very easy to go there along and quickly jump into conversations with other patrons. They often had live bands playing in the bar area, which meant that navigating from the narrow alley to the bar meant getting close enough to the band to smell their freshness. Coding lessons learned The website development was an awesome learning opportunity, as I had to plan and develop the project from proposal to deployment. There were several lessons I learned from it that I wanted to capture before it escapes my mind. - They won’t respect you, if you just follow the spec. I met a young web designer at Mou one night who essentially said that web developers who take the spec and produce exactly what it has are amateurs. He spoke about the developer he works with who takes the specs and comes back with better designs, more animation, and a more unique customer experience. He gave me a few examples that really got me pumped to do the same with my work. Unfortunately, I met this guy near the end of the project and really didn’t do this one. Also, if you see something in the spec that you don’t agree with, but go ahead and include in the site, then there is a 100% chance that someone down the line is going to ask you why you did it that way. Saying that the spec said so is a pretty shitty response. - It’s all about your relationships and understanding peoples roles. I made the terrible mistake of not interacting or getting feedback often enough from the content managers, but instead only from the designer. By only working with other technical people on the client side, you are going to make design decisions that work for technical people, not end users. Find out who will be using your site in what way, and make sure that they are involved in the design and acceptance of functionality early on. - Welcome the clients desire for change. We developers have a bad reputation for hemming and hawing whenever the client wants something changes. This makes us look like whiners, instead of technologist who know that some changes take more time then a client might expect. I can think of two ways to handle this. When writing any line of code, ask yourself “how might they want to change this functionality in the future?” If it is possible to put the value in a config, or make the functionality tweakable from a user interface, then it might be worth it to do that upfront instead of having to go in and change the code later. Another way to handle this is to have a solid contract that lays out change management in a way that protects you and gets the client what they need. If possible, outline from the beginning what will be developed and clearly state in the contact and in the planning meetings that changes to the design will likely take more time and that you are not keen on working 90-hour weeks. - Add 20-30% on your initial estimate. I felt nervous doing this up front, and which I had. It would have saved me from having to ask for more time in the end and would have given the client a more complete picture up front. My estimation included all the scoped functionality development, testing, and deployment, but did not include time for minor design changes, meetings, and unforeseen technical issues. These latter items are often difficult to estimate, making the 20-30% a decent way to try to plan ahead for them. General thoughts I feel that my life is a great big exclamation point. I have gone from using one or two a year to using a minimum of 2 in every email or note to a friend. I didn’t even really notice it until my buddy Josh called me out after an email with 5 or 6 of them in there. My inner monolog feels like it is yelling with excitement all of the time, and I think that comes out in my notes. The excitement comes from looking forward to every part of the day. When I wake up, I am excited to make some gangster veggified eggs. After breakfast I am usually stoked to have some mate and meditate/be still for a bit. Then its on to the days activities which could be coding, going to the beach, finding a van, writing, meeting up with new friends, running, biking, yada yada. I look forward to all the meals throughout the day because it’s another chance to create something new that might taste great or might bomb. At night I look forward to chillen with the flatties, going into town to find a new bar or coffee shop to try, or reading more of Steve Jobs massive biography. Then I get stoked to sleep and as I am getting ready I fall asleep I usually start getting pumped for eggs the next morning. Sometimes the pumpedness is too much and I have trouble sleeping, but that’s only happened a few times. The intense feelings seem to go both ways though. When I am a bit lonely or more often, recounting some regretful things I have done that hurt people, then those thoughts and feelings are very real and troublesome. Luckily they emotions don’t stick around too long and I can get backed to thinking about what veggies will be in tomorrow mash up.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: "I feel that my life is a great big exclamation point." Love this. So happy for you!
When are you and Colin coming to join me on the road?

item.title: Updates from New Zealand
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Alright, I need to get a post out the door.  This one has been in progress for 2 months - not from taking time to make it great, but from the nice distractions of living with others and creating a life in a new city.  This post has even less editing than usual.  I apologize for poor grammar and any rambling.  With that low expectation set, enjoy yourself. [gallery link="file"] A Tiki-Tour with my Ma Heaps has happened in the month since I have written a bit. It’s about time to get it all down. After completing my month of living and working in Dunedin, my mom came down to do a tiki-tour of the South and North Island of New Zealand. We had 3 weeks to see the country, which felt like plenty during the planning phase, but after a few days on the road we quickly realized that seeing everything wasn’t going to be in the cards. Not a problem though, as even a week in this country would be worth it. The highlights of the trip included: getting my mom to sleep in the back of a van in the middle of nowhere (the Catlins), taking an overnight cruise of Doubtful Sound, watching part of Fox Glacier fall in its daily ritual of decline, sleeping in a parking lot in Wellington, visiting friends all over the country, and getting a chance to chat with my mom on long rides in our Toyota Town Ace. When I was younger I never had much of an interest in hearing my mom’s stories or even chatting with her about the issues of my day to day life. That was part of how we did things in the family and also had a lot to do with being an adolescent guy and just not wanting to hang out with my mom. But now, thinking about how much she has sacrificed for me, and how much of her life she has dedicated to raising my siblings and I, I realized thought she deserves a trip like this. To get out of the house and out of the daily routine. To start new habits, if only for 3 weeks that were sans cleaning, cooking, and running errands. It was a chance for her to be the center of attention and pampering, after she has done much for others over the years. She was a teacher for 40+ years serving the youths of Houston, and now volunteers at local schools, our church, and provides for neighbors who cannot provide for themselves. She is a remarkable woman and I was very happy to spend time with her! Thanks for coming mom.   The East Coast: First to see the Sun After my mom flew out of Auckland, I headed over to the East coast via the Urewera Forest. This is probably one of the most untouched areas of New Zealand. It is mostly populated by Maori tribes that are still living by the land. The roads are a mix of gravel and pavement, and it was not an uncommon sight to see cattle wandering the winding roads of the gorge. You even catch Maori cowboys heading to and from jobs on the road. I stayed in the forest for the night and went on a few short hikes to lakes and waterfalls. It’s a very long drive to get through the area, but is worth it if you are keen to get away from the summer holiday rush. For New Years, I went to the Rhythm and Vines festival in Gisborne with Beale, from Dunedin, and Liam and Duncan who are my roommates here in New Plymouth. The festival was not everything we were hoping for, as the bands were mediocre at best. The venue was sweet though. It took place in a wine vineyard that was in a valley just outside of town. They crammed 30,000 people into the area, who did not give those grapes the respect and dignity of being immune to the bodily functions that often result from too much partying. They also had a massive slide carved out of a hill that launched you into a muddy pit. More than a few girls and guys found this to be a great opportunity to get naked in public. Good on them! I stayed with Beale’s mom and siblings in Gisborne and also spent a few nights in Hicks Bay, up the coast, with his grandma. She is what you might call a “switched on” lady. She is very active at 81 - teaching at the local school, running services at church, and presiding over countless important family events that require the gentle hand and helpful ear of a priest. We had a few great conversations about American politics, the plight of the Maoris in her area, how easy child rearing is if you simply listen to them, and about her lovely grandchild that, at four years old, is more intelligent than many adults. I also got to witness a competitive tribal field day called the Pa Wars. Maoris from many of the tribes on the East coast come together every 2 years to compete in such events as foot races, sheep shearing competitions, rugby games, and impressive tug-of-wars. I think the best part of the events were that they often had people of every age group competing together. In the relay races, you could have 6 year olds leading the teams out of the blocks and 65 year old men and women giving everything they had to bring it home. It is definitely worth the trip if you are ever near one. “Fasting” and Reflection After loving the big meals of the holidays and my oh-so-gracious hosts on the East coast, I decided to take an adventure that I have had on my bucket list for a while. That adventure was to spend an extended amount of time in the woods without any food. The attraction comes from the inherit risk involved and the possibility of change. Would I not look at food the same way? Would I find a higher appreciation for the wilderness and nature? Would I sort out long standing issues that cause me a good deal of guilt? Would I feel euphoric just sitting under the trees, with no desire to eat or consume anything but air? Unfortunately it was not that romantic. The 5-day and 4-night adventure started the day I left Gisborne. I stopped at a town library to download a copy of The Master Cleanse, which outlines a lemonade diet that is suppose to provide enough energy to get through the day and clean out your system. I read the book by lunchtime and decided that I would head out to the Pureora Forest with a bag of lemons, an elusive bottle of blackstrap molasses, and a box of cayenne pepper. By evening I was sipping on the potent mixture of these fine ingredients and waiting for the hunger to set in. I setout to hike around the tree-sitter saved native forest of the Pureora Forest. The mentality at that point was to hike for at least an hour to see if I had enough energy after only having eaten breakfast that day. I had plenty of energy and what felt like massive amounts of time as there was no time spent prepping, eating, and cleaning up from a meal. I walked a loop trail about 6 times, while mentally ironing out the web of guilt created from a previous relationship. The repetition of placing one foot in front of the other and becoming more familiar with the short loop led to a comforting feeling of being somewhere familiar. This somehow brought about a very clear state of mind. I was able to focus very intently on one area of guilt, recall the circumstances of the accusation, recollect my intentions at the time, and then separate the valid criticisms from heated accusations. It was a painfully honest self-realization, but one that left me with ideas for how to do better. The main lesson being that if you have goals/dreams that only include yourself, then be honest with yourself and your partner about them. Hmm, that got heavy pretty quickly! Back to the fasting hiking sesh. The next morning I visiting with the resident DOC staffer and got the low down on the multi-day hikes in the area and exit strategies if things got messy. Luckily, the main route was setup in a way that there were paths out to roads every 4-5 hours. That way, I could assess each morning if I had the energy to continue, or if I needed to head out for burgers and beers. Fortunately, or unfortunately, depending on the goals which you assess the success of the trip, I never needed to make an emergency exit, but did not cover as much ground as the original aggressive plan I had laid out. During the short week out there, I never felt hungry, and cravings were minimal, as there was not a delicious kabab shop at each bend of the trail. It was very surprising to me that I didn’t feel that I needed food even when hiking 4 hours a day. I thought at times that it would be nice to have an apple or granola bar, but did not feel that it was a necessity to provide energy to keep moving. If my mind started to drift to thoughts of Honey BBQ chicken wings, I would hike faster to increase my focus on where my feet were on the sketchy trails or try to find something more interesting to think about. I did not have any enlightening moments or feelings of euphoria, but I did read all of The Audacity of Hope, and enjoyed spending time in the bush. The take away for me was how little the body needs to function, but I also realized that I do enjoy food and wouldn’t be a happy man if I had to drink lemonade and pepper for the rest of my life. A good friend said that journeys like this should be marked. I marked this trip by committing to cut out most types of meat from my life. Flat Life in New Plymouth I am currently living in NP, which is on the West coast of the North Island of New Zealand. It is not on the main tourist route, which means that on sunny Saturdays you can find black sand, teal blue water and beaches nearly empty. I am working/living with a good guy named Andy, who has Down's syndrome. His mother has setup an impressive situation, which allows Andy to have a caregiver for most weekdays and then he comes home to a house of internationals who provide entertainment, meals, and any guidance that he might need. As the two other guys I am living with say, it is not really work, as Andy is just another one of the guys. He is actually an amazing roommate as he likes to cook, dry dishes, and LOVES doing laundry. Beyond that though, he is actually a very caring guy and has a way of making you want to smile or dance at any time of day. He could also be nominated to the Nobel Peace Prize for the warmth and calmness that is the result of one of his bear hugs. Beyond the flat, I have been having a great time exploring “the Naki (Taranaki)”. There is volcano about 50km down the road and you can see it from the back porch of the house we live at. There is an awesome bike ride that starts with an hour long climb looking straight at the mountain and then it turns into a 30 minute downhill with a view out to the ocean and the sugarloaf islands just off the coast. The downhill definitely makes the climb worth the effort. There are also a few rivers coming down from mountains and hills, which provide at least 3 solid spots for cliff jumps. They are tree jumps, cliffs, and big rope swings. It’s a candy-land for the adventurous spirit. The best cliff jump in the area is out on the coast. Between two of the sugarloaf islands is a narrow channel called Shark alley. You can climb up the face of one of the islands, lookout over the beach and cliffs, yell out something to get you fired up (“Woo! America Day! **** Yeah!”), and leap 50ft to the cold clear water below. It is also nice to live with two guys who are always down for an adventure. Liam, the Yorkshire Tree Surgeon, is never too tired to get in a cheeky cliff jump or surf at sunset on back beach. Duncan, the Irishman who couldn’t sound more English, is down for hiking and river sessions, but also has an incredible arsenal of beats that he pumps into the house, providing yet another reason to have a dance party. It has been a few great months and I continue to feel blessed to have met such great people and been able to experience some beautiful places.

item.title: Dancing, screaming, touching
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Written a few weeks ago...
As a background for this story, I should mention that I am living with a good guy named Andy, who has Downs Syndrome. Myself and two other internationals prepare meals with him and help him to live a normal life. What has been more true of the situation is that he helps us actually live life.
This past weekend the WOMAD festival came to town and Andy was more than excited to take us there. The festival, described as “WOMAD - World of Music, Arts and Dance the internationally established Festival, which brings together artists from all over the globe. The central aim of the WOMAD festival is to celebrate the world's many forms of music, arts and dance.” It is an amazing opportunity to see how diverse, but equally inspiring, music can be.
The Friday of the festival featured the Master Drummers of Burundi, a collection of 12 drummers from one of the 5 poorest countries in the world. The rhythm pounded out by them could be felt far beyond the moat surrounding the stage. After a few minutes of experiencing the music, the urge to dance was too much to ignore and I noticed that Andy was looking to get involved as well. We got to our feet and my first sensation was that it was nice warm up to a cool evening in the Pukekura Park. Andy began to dance modestly, but quickly appeared to become more and more entranced in the beat. As the moderateness gave way to more free-flowing dancing his arms, legs, and booty were going in all directions,which was now bringing smiles to faces around us. It was not long before the freeing feeling of the tribal tones engulfed our bodies and minds. We ran with the feeling, ripping off our shirts, exposing our bare chests to the ourselves, to the crowd, to the trees, to the stars. The dancing was becomingincreasingly frantic and exciting enough to get another flatmate, Liam, involved in the madness. At some point during Andy’s monkey/booty dance, he started to shout to the moon. He let out a few deep bellows that one might expect to hear around the drum circle on the backlands of Burundi. The urge to shout overcame Liam and I as we danced harder and more freely. Next up on the emotional roller coaster being fueled by the Master Drummers, was the feeling of touch. It started with friendly bumping, shoving, and embracing, but led to Andy grabbed me and pulled me to the ground. The empty space between disappeared. There was Andy, there was Andrew, but for a moment we were emotionally on the same level and the feeling of connectedness, of oneness was very real. Smiles were shared, and the feeling of happiness and love grew deeper. We wrestled about for a bit and slowly the music faded out, taking with it the intensity of the moment.
Humans are special creatures, but it can be surprising at how simple things such as touch, letting your voice go, and dance can be so uplifting. In a society threatened by child molestation, family abuse, homophobia, rape, etc., it feels as though the simple pleasures of human touch are escaping us. We are constantly surrounded by people...co-workers, friends, strangers on the street, and family...but how often do we experience touch outside the boundaries of a physical relationship? The progression of that freeing feeling of dancing and screaming was embracing one another. This was not an expression of homo-eroticness and it was not an expression of taking advantage of one another. It was an expression of trust, of love, of the reality that we are all humans no matter our background or disabilities. We are creatures of the same cloth, whether you believe it is sowed by science or God.
Love yourself. Love your neighbor. Hug somebody.
[gallery link="file"]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: So true! Sometimes people just need a hug! I have many to give out! There is joy is that physical connection w another human being. I've also always said that dancing is the most sincere expression of joy there is. There is alterior motive to it, no ego. Just the uncontainable need to feel that music fueled happiness all through your body. Go Roomie Andy for spreadin that joy so freely!!
